tr.td: True iff G is in this graph class.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff the treewidth of G is at most k (see bounded treewidth).

Problem.name: Cliquewidth
Problem.note:
Whether the cliquewidth of the graphs in this class is bounded by a constant k.
The cliquewidth of a graph is the number of different labels that is needed to construct the graph using the following operations:
creation of a vertex with label i,
disjoint union,
renaming labels i to label j,
connecting all vertices with label i to all vertices with label j.

tr.td: A graph G in this class.

An expression that constructs G according to the rules for cliquewidth, using only a constant number of labels.
Undefined if this class has unbounded cliquewidth.
A graph G in this class with weight function on the vertices and a real k.
True iff G contains a set S of pairwise non-adjacent vertices, such that the sum of the weights of the vertices in S is at least k.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff G contains a set S of pairwise non-adjacent vertices, such that |S| >= k.
A graph G in this class with weight function on the vertices and a real k.
True iff G contains a set S of pairwise non-adjacent vertices, with the sum of the weights of the vertices in S at most k, such that every vertex in G is either in S or adjacent to a vertex in S.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff G contains a set S of pairwise non-adjacent vertices, with |S| <= k, such that every vertex in G is either in S or adjacent to a vertex in S.
A graph G in this class with weight function on the vertices and a real k.
True iff G contains a set S of pairwise adjacent vertices, such that the sum of the weights of the vertices in S is at least k.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff G contains a set S of pairwise adjacent vertices, with |S| >= k.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff G contains a set S of vertices, with |S| <= k, such that every vertex in G is either in S or adjacent to a vertex in S.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff each vertex of G can be assigned one colour out of k such that whenever two vertices are adjacent, they have different colours.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff the vertices of G can be partitioned into k sets Si, such that whenever two vertices are in the same set Si, they are adjacent.
A graph G in this class.
True iff each vertex of G can be assigned one colour out of 3 such that whenever two vertices are adjacent, they have different colours.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff the cutwidth of G is at most k (see bounded cutwidth).
A graph G in this class.
True iff G has a simple cycle that goes through every vertex of the graph.
A graph G in this class.
True iff G has a simple path that goes through every vertex of the graph.
A graph G in this class with weight function on the vertices and a real k.
True iff G contains a set S of vertices, such that the sum of the weights of the vertices in S is at most k and every cycle in G contains a vertex from S.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff G contains a set S of vertices, with |S| <= k, such that every cycle in G contains a vertex from S.

Problem.name: Weighted maximum cut
Problem.note:
(decision variant)
Input:A graph G in this class with weight function on the edges and a real k.
Output:True iff the vertices of G can be partitioned into two sets A,B such that the sum of weights of the edges in G with one endpoint in A and the other endpoint in B is at least k.

Problem.name: Maximum cut
Problem.note:
(decision variant)
Input:A graph G in this class and an integer k.
Output:True iff the vertices of G can be partitioned into two sets A,B such that there are at least k edges in G with one endpoint in A and the other endpoint in B.

Problem.name: Maximum bisection
Problem.note:
(decision variant)
Input:A graph G in this class and an integer k.
Output:True iff the vertices of G can be partitioned into two sets A,B of equal size (or |A|=|B|-1 if G has an odd number of vertices) such that there are at least k edges in G with one endpoint in A and the other endpoint in B.

Problem.name: Minimum bisection
Problem.note:
(decision variant)
Input:A graph G in this class and an integer k.
Output:True iff the vertices of G can be partitioned into two sets A,B of equal size (or |A|=|B|-1 if G has an odd number of vertices) such that there are at most k edges in G with one endpoint in A and the other endpoint in B.

GraphClass.name: pseudo--split
GraphClass.note: A graph is called gc_2 if it is gc_1.

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--brittle
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_3 if it contains an independent set S such that either every P_4 has a midpoint in S or every P_4 has an endpoint in S.

GraphClass.name: perfectly orderable
GraphClass.note: A vertex order < of G is perfect iff G contains no P_4 abcd with a < b and d < c. A graph is gc_4 if it admits a perfect order.

algo.name: Weighted clique
algo.note: Assuming a perfect order is given ref_1424

algo.name: Colourability
algo.note: Assuming a perfect order is given ref_1424 ref_1382

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--bipartite
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_5 if its vertex set can be partitioned in two subsets, each of which induces a gc_152 graph.

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--comparability
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_6 if it admits an acyclic orientation in which each induced P_4 is of the type: o->o<-o->o

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--extendible
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_7 if for any subset W of G that contains a P_4 there exists at most one vertex x in G-W such that x forms a P_4 with vertices in W.

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--tidy
GraphClass.note:
A partner of a P_4 A in G is a vertex v in G-A such that A+v induces at least two P_4s.
A graph G is gc_8 if any P_4 has at most one partner.

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--laden
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_9 if every induced subgraph with at most six vertices that contains more than two induced P_4s is a gc_39 graph.

GraphClass.name: brittle
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_10 iff each induced subgraph H of G contains either a vertex that is not the endpoint of any P_4 of H, or a vertex that is not the midpoint of any P_4 of H.

GraphClass.name: extended $P_4$--laden
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_11 if every induced subgraph with at most six vertices that contains more than two induced P_4s is a gc_2 graph.

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--lite
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_12 if every induced subgraph H of G with at most six vertices that contains more than two induced P_4s is isomorphic to S_3 or to \co{S_3}.

GraphClass.name: weakly chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_14 if it is gc_435.

A 2-pair in a graph is a pair of non-adjacent vertices x, y such that every chordless path has exactly two edges.
A graph is gc_14 if every connected induced subgraph H that is not a complete graph, contains a 2-pair.

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--reducible
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_15 if every vertex belongs to at most one P_4

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--sparse
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_18 if every set of five vertices contains at most one induced P_4.

GraphClass.name: extended $P_4$--reducible
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_19 if it is gc_461.

GraphClass.name: forest--perfect
GraphClass.note:
The P_4-structureref_206 of a graph G is a hypergraph having the nodes of G as its vertex set and all 4-element vertex sets inducing a P_4 in G as its hyperedges.
A graph is gc_20 iff it has the P_4-structure of a forest.

GraphClass.name: HHDS--free
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_21 if it is gc_232.

GraphClass.name: permutation
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_23 graph iff it has an intersection model consisting of straight lines (one per vertex) between two parallels.

GraphClass.name: alternately orientable
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_25 iff it admits an orientation in which no chordless cycle of length at least 4 contains a directed P_3.

GraphClass.name: extended $P_4$--sparse
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_26 iff it is gc_189.

GraphClass.name: superbrittle
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_27 iff in every induced subgraph of G no vertex is both a midpoint of an induced P_4 and an endpoint of an induced P_4.

GraphClass.name: Welsh--Powell opposition
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_28 graph if it is an gc_89 graph for every order satisfying x < y whenever degree(x) >= degree(y).
A graph is a gc_28 graph if for every induced P_4 abcd: d(b) > d(a) and d(c) > d(d).

GraphClass.name: chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_32 if every cycle of length at least 4 has a chord.

A graph G is gc_32 if it is the intersection graph of subtrees of a tree T. In particular T can be chosen such that each node of T corresponds to a maximal clique of G and the subtrees Tv consist of precisely those maximal cliques in G that contain v. T is then called the clique tree of G.
A graph G is gc_32 if every minimal cutset in every induced subgraph of G is a clique.

A vertex v of G is called simplicial in G if N(v) is a clique in G.
The ordering v1...vn of the vertices of G is a perfect elimination order of G if for all i, vi is simplicial in G[v1...vi].
A graph is gc_32 if it has a perfect elimination order.

GraphClass.name: $\tau_k$--perfect for all $k \ge 2$
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_35 if for every subgraph H we have for the hypergraph H' formed by all trees of diameter at most k>=2 in H that alpha(H') = kappa(H'), where alpha is the packing number (max. vertex set such that every hyperedge contains at most one vertex from the set) and kappa the covering number (min. edge set that contains all vertices).

GraphClass.name: split
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_39 graph if it can be partitioned in an independent set and a clique.

GraphClass.name: 2--interval
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_40 iff it has an intersection model whose objects consist of 2 intervals on a real line.

GraphClass.name: 3--interval
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_41 iff it has an intersection model whose objects consist of 3 intervals on a real line.

GraphClass.name: 2--outerplanar
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_42 iff it is gc_1184 for k=2.

GraphClass.name: planar
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_43 if it can be embedded in the plane (drawn with points for vertices and curves for edges) without crossing edges.

algo.name: Independent set
algo.note: Even when the maximum degree is at most 6 ref_421.

algo.name: Hamiltonian cycle
algo.note: Even when cubic and 3-connected ref_1539.

algo.name: Hamiltonian cycle
algo.note: Even when cubic and cyclically 4-connected ref_1540.

GraphClass.name: 2--threshold
GraphClass.note: A graph is k-threshold iff its threshold dimension is at most k.

GraphClass.name: absolute bipartite retract
GraphClass.note:
A retraction from a graph H to a subgraph G is mapping of V(H) to V(G) such that 1) every node in G is mapped to itself and 2) every edge of H is mapped to an edge of G.
G is an absolute retract if G is a retract of every graph H containing G as an isometric subgraph, provided that \chi(G) = \chi(H), where \chi is the chromatic number.
A graph is an gc_45 if it is gc_69 and an absolute retract.

GraphClass.name: half--disk Helly
GraphClass.note:
A half-disk with center u and radius k is the set of nodes v such that d(u,v) <= k and d(u,v) is even, or the set of nodes v such that d(u,v) <= k an d(u,v) is odd.
The half-disk hypergraph of a bipartite graph B has V(B) as vertex set and its half-disks in B as hyperedges.
A gc_69 graph is gc_46 if its half-disk hypergraph has the Helly property.

GraphClass.name: dismantlable
GraphClass.note:
K_1 is gc_49.
G (with at least 2 vertices) is gc_49 iff there exist vertices y,z such that N[z] \subseteq N[y] (y dominates z) and G(V-z) is gc_49.

GraphClass.name: modular
GraphClass.note: G is gc_50 if for every three vertices x,y,z there exists a vertex w that lies on a shortest path between every two of x, y,z; i.e. if every metric triangle has size 0.

GraphClass.name: open--neighbourhood--Helly
GraphClass.note:
The open-neighbourhood hypergraph of G has V(G) as its vertices and the open neighbourhood N(v) of all vertices v in V(G) as its hyperedges.
A graph is gc_51 iff its open-neighbourhood hypergraph has the Helly property.

GraphClass.name: absolute reflexive retract
GraphClass.note:
A retraction of a graph H to a subgraph G is vertex mapping such that every edge of H is mapped to an edge of G and every vertex in G is mapped to itself.
G is an absolute retract if G is a retract of every graph H with chi(G) = chi(H) that contains G as an isometric subgraph, where chi is the chromatic number.
A graph is an gc_52 if it is gc_581 and is an absolute retract.

GraphClass.name: clique--Helly
GraphClass.note:
The clique hypergraph of G has V(G) as its vertices and the cliques (maximal complete subgraphs) of G as its hyperedges.
A graph is gc_54 iff its clique hypergraph has the Helly property.

An extended triangle of G is the subgraph induced by a triangle T together with all vertices that are adjacent to at least two vertices of T.
A graph is gc_54 iff every of its extended triangles contains a universal vertex.

GraphClass.name: absorbantly perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_55 if every induced subgraph H has a minimal dominating (=absorbant) set meeting all maximal cliques in H.

GraphClass.name: perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_56 if for all induced subgraphs H: \chi(H) = \omega(H), where \chi is the chromatic number and \omega is the size of a maximum clique.

GraphClass.name: bip$^*$
GraphClass.note:
A star-cutset C is a cutset that contains a vertex that is adjacent to all other vertices in C.
Every bipartite graph is in gc_57.
If G or \co{G} has a star-cutset, and G-v is in gc_57 for all vertices v of G, then G is in gc_57.

GraphClass.name: trapezoid
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_59 graph if it is the intersection graph of trapezoids between two parallel lines.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Timebound valid only when given the modelref_1120; otherwise O(V^2).

algo.name: Weighted clique
algo.note: Timebound valid only when given the modelref_1120.

algo.name: Clique cover
algo.note: Timebound valid only when given the modelref_1120.

algo.name: Colourability
algo.note: Timebound valid only when given the modelref_1120.

GraphClass.name: AT--free
GraphClass.note:
Three vertices of a graph form an asteroidal triple if every two of them are connected by a path avoiding the neighbourhood of the third.
A graph is gc_61 if it does not contain any asteroidal triple.

GraphClass.name: strict quasi--parity
GraphClass.note:
Two vertices form an even pair if all chordless paths between them have even length.
G is gc_65 if each induced subgraph of G is complete or has an even pair.

GraphClass.name: biconvex
GraphClass.note:
An ordering < of X in a bipartite graph B=(X,Y,E) has the adjacency property if for every vertex y in Y, N(y) consists of vertices that are consecutive (an interval) in the ordering < of X.
A bipartite graph (X,Y,E) is gc_66 if there is an ordering of X and Y that fulfills the adjacency property.

GraphClass.name: convex
GraphClass.note:
An ordering < of X in a bipartite graph B=(X,Y,E) has the adjacency property if for every vertex y in Y, N(y) consists of vertices that are consecutive (an interval) in the ordering < of X.
A bipartite graph (X,Y,E) is gc_67 if there is an ordering of X or Y that fulfills the adjacency property.

GraphClass.name: bipartable

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: Constructing G' and testing bipartiteness can be done polynomially ref_544.

GraphClass.name: bipartite
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_69 if its vertex set can be partitioned into 2 independent sets.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Variant of matching.

GraphClass.name: comparability
GraphClass.note:
The gc_72 graph of a partial order (V,<=) has node set V and edge xy whenever x<=y or y<=x.
G is a gc_72 if it is the comparability graph of some poset.
G is a gc_72 if it transitively orientable, i.e. its edges can be directed such that if a->b and b->c are directed edges, then a->c is a directed edge.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: with $a$ the arboricity of the graph ref_1643

GraphClass.name: Gallai
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_73 iff it is gc_192.

GraphClass.name: Gallai--perfect
GraphClass.note:
The Gallai graph Gallai(G) or \Gamma(G) of a graph G=(V,E) has E as its vertex set and ef is an edge in Gallai(G) if in G e and f are incident (share a vertex) but do not span a triangle. (In other words, e and f induce a P_3 in G.)
cf. gc_73.
G is gc_74 if Gallai(G) has no induced odd holes.

GraphClass.name: parity
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_75 graph if for any two induced paths joining the same pair of vertices the path lengths have the same parity (odd or even).

GraphClass.name: chordal bipartite
GraphClass.note: A gc_69 graph is gc_79 if each cycle of length at least 6 has a chord.

Let $G=(X,Y,E)$ be a gc_69 graph. An edge $(x,y)$ is called bisimplicial if $N(x)\cup N(y)$ induces a complete bipartite graph in $G$.
Let $(e_1,\dots,e_m)$ be an ordering of the edges of $G$. Let $G_0=G$ and $G_i = G_{i-1} \setminus e_i$ ($G_i$ is obtained from $G_{i-1}$ by removing the edge $e_i$ but not its endvertices). The ordering $(e_1,\dots,e_m)$ is a perfect edge-without-vertex elimination ordering if $e_i$ is bisimplicial in $G_{i-1}$ for all $1\le i\le m$.
A gc_69 graph is gc_79 if it admits a perfect edge-without-vertex elimination ordering.
Let $G=(X,Y,E)$ be a gc_69 graph. Let $G'$ be the graph obtained from $G$ by adding an edge between every pair of vertices in $X$. A gc_69 graph $G$ is gc_79 if $G'$ is gc_125.
Note these are not gc_32 because induced C_4s are allowed. The name gc_116 is clearer.

GraphClass.name: distance--hereditary
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_80 if it is connected and every induced path is isometric; that is, if the distance function in every induced subgraph of G is the same as in G itself.

A graph G is gc_80 if it can be construct from a single vertex by the following operations:
Adding a pendant vertex: A new vertex that is adjacent to precisely one existing vertex of the graph.
Creating true twins: For an existing vertex x add a new vertex y with neighbours N[x].
Creating false twins: For an existing vertex x add a new vertex y with neighbours N(x).

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Hammer/Maffray's ref_511 algorithm contained an error that was corrected by Nicolai.ref_809

GraphClass.name: bipartite permutation
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_81 graph, if it is both gc_69 and a gc_23 graph.

A strong ordering (<A, <B) of a gc_69 graph G = (A, B, E) consists of an ordering <A of A and an ordering <B of B, such that for all edges ab, a'b', with a,a' in A and b,b' in B: If a <A a' and b <B b', then ab' and a'b are edges.
A gc_69 graph is a gc_81 graph iff it admits a strong ordering.
Note that there is another definition of a strong ordering in gc_320.

Let G = (A, B, E) be a gc_69 graph. An ordering < of A has the adjacency property, if, for every vertex b in B, N(b) consits of vertices that are consecutive in <. An ordering < of A has the enclosure property, if, for every pair b,b' of vertices in B with N(b) \subseteq N(b'), the vertices of N(b')\N(b) appear consecutively in <, implying that b is adjacent to the leftmost or rightmost neighbour of b' in <.
A gc_69 graph G = (A, B, E) is a gc_81 graph iff it admits an ordering of A that has the adjacency and enclosure properties.

GraphClass.name: X--star--chordal
GraphClass.note:
Let B=(X,Y,E) be a gc_69 graph and C a cycle in B. C has an X-star if there is a vertex x in X-C, such that x is adjacent to at least 3 vertices of C.
B is gc_85 if every chordless cycle of length at least 6 contains an X-star.

GraphClass.name: bipolarizable
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_87 if it admits an acyclic orientation in which each induced P_4 is of the type: o<-o->o->o

GraphClass.name: opposition
GraphClass.note: A graph is an gc_89 graph if it has an acyclic orientation that does not contain o->o->o->o or o->o<-o->o has an induced subgraph.
A graph is an gc_89 graph it has an ordering < such that no P_4 abcd has a<b and c<d.

GraphClass.name: weak bipolarizable
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_90 if it is gc_351.
A graph is gc_90 if it is modularly decomposable into chordal graphs.

GraphClass.name: bithreshold
GraphClass.note: G is a gc_91 graph if it is the edge intersection of two gc_328 graphs T,U such that every independent set of G is independent in T or in U.

GraphClass.name: 2--split
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_92 if its vertex set can be partitioned into 2 sets, each of which induces a split graph.

GraphClass.name: block
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_93 graph if it is connected and every block (maximal 2-connected component) is a clique.
A graph is a gc_93 graph if it can be constructed from a gc_342 by replacing every edge by a clique of arbitrary size; the cliques have at most one vertex in common.

A graph is a gc_93 graph if for every four vertices u,v,w,x the larger two of the distance sums
d(u,v)+ d(w,x)
d(u,w)+ d(v,x)
d(u,x)+ d(v,w)
are equal.
A graph is a gc_93 graph if for every four vertices u,v,w,x the d(u,v)+ d(w,x) <= max( d(u,w)+ d(v,x), d(u,x)+ d(v,w) ).

GraphClass.name: ptolemaic
GraphClass.note: A connected graph is gc_95 if any four vertices u,v,w,x satisfy the ptolemaic inequality: d(u,v) d(w,x) <= d(u,w) d(v,x) + d(u,x) d(v,w).

GraphClass.name: geodetic
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_96 if for every pair for vertices the shortest path between them is unique.

GraphClass.name: bounded tolerance
GraphClass.note: A gc_97 graph is a gc_169 graph in which the tolerances are bounded by the length of the corresponding intervals.

GraphClass.name: intersection graphs of parallelograms (squares)
GraphClass.note: A graph is an gc_98 if it is a gc_59 graph in which all trapezoids are parallelograms.

GraphClass.name: bridged
GraphClass.note: A bridge of a cycle C is a shortest path in G joining nonconsecutive vertices of C, which is shorter than both the paths of C joining those vertices. G is gc_99 if every cycle of length at least 4 has a bridge (i.e. the only isometric cycles in G can be of length 3).

GraphClass.name: Helly
GraphClass.note:
A set S of sets Si has the Helly property if for every subset T of S the following hold: if the elements of T pairwise intersect, then the intersection of all elements of T is also non-empty.
The disk hypergraph of G has V(G) has its vertices and the disks D(v,k), v in V(G), k>=1 as its edge sets, where D(v,k) is the set of vertices that have distance at most k to v.
A graph is gc_105 (or disk Helly) if its disk hypergraph has the Helly property.

Let K(G) be the gc_141 graph of G, K0(G) = G and Ki+1(G) = K(Ki(G)). G is called clique-convergent if for some i, Ki+1(G) is isomorphic to Ki(G).
A graph is gc_105 iff it is gc_54 and clique-convergent.

GraphClass.name: domination
GraphClass.note:
A vertex ordering v1...vn of G=(V,E) is a domination ordering if for all i there is a j such that vi is dominated by vj in Gi, i.e. N(vi) is a subset of N[vj].
G is a gc_106 graph if every induced subgraph has a domination elimination ordering.

GraphClass.name: quasi--brittle
GraphClass.note:
An edge ab of G is a symmetric wing if there exist vertices c,d,p,q such that both abcd and bapq are P_4s in G.
A graph is gc_107 if every induced subgraph H contains a vertex incident with no symmetric wing in H and \co{H}.

GraphClass.name: cactus
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_108 if every edge is part of at most one cycle.
They can be constructed from trees by replacing every edge by a cycle of arbitrary size; the cycles have at most one vertex in common.

GraphClass.name: almost tree (1)
GraphClass.note: A graph is an almost tree (k) if every biconnected component has the property that there are at most k edges not in a spanning tree of this biconnected component.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: for fixed k

GraphClass.name: outerplanar
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_110 if it has a crossing-free embedding in the plane such that all vertices are on the same face.

GraphClass.name: circle-polygon
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_111 graph if it is the intersection graph of convex polygons inscribed in a circle.

A graph is a gc_111 graph if there exists a bijection from vertices to sets of connected non-intersecting chords inscribed in a circle such that two vertices are adjacent iff their sets contains at least one pair of intersecting chords.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: A polynomial algorithm was announced in ref_679 but never published. Deciding the smallest k such that all polygons are k-gons is NP-complete ref_1237.

GraphClass.name: good
GraphClass.note:
An ordering < on G is good if for any induced subgraph H of G either the largest vertex of (H,<) is simplicial in H or the smallest vertex of (H,<) is simplicial in \co{H}.
A graph is gc_112 if it admits a good ordering.

GraphClass.name: slightly triangulated
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_114 if it is gc_437 and for every induced subgraph H there is a vertex v in H such that the neighbourhood of v in H contains no P_4

GraphClass.name: perfect elimination bipartite
GraphClass.note:
An edge (u,v) in a gc_69 graph is called bisimplicial if N(u)\cup N(v) induces a biclique in B.
For an edge ordering e1...ek let Si be the set of endpoints of e1...ei.
e1...ek is a perfect edge elimination ordering for a gc_69 graph B=(V,E) if B[V\Sk] has no edges, and each edge ei is bisimplicial in B[V\Si].
B is gc_122 if it admits a perfect edge elimination ordering.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of dimension 4 posets
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_124 if it is the gc_72 of a poset of dimension 4. (The dimension of a poset P is the minimal number of linear extensions of P whose intersection is P.)

GraphClass.name: strongly chordal
GraphClass.note:
A chord xy in an even cycle C is odd, when the distance in C between x and y is odd.
A graph is gc_125 if it is chordal and every cycle of even length at least 6 has an odd chord.

A perfect elimination ordering (see gc_32) of a graph G is a strong perfect elimination ordering if for all i<j, k<l: if vivk, vivl, vjvk are edges, then vjvl is an edge.
A graph is gc_125 if it has a strong perfect elimination ordering.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: The linear time recognition algorithm in ref_1467 was later withdrawn.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: with $a$ the arboricity of the graph ref_1643

GraphClass.name: EPT
GraphClass.note: gc_128 graphs are the Edge intersection graphs of non-trivial Paths in a Tree.

GraphClass.name: undirected path
GraphClass.note: gc_129 graphs are the vertex intersection graphs of undirected paths in an undirected tree.

GraphClass.name: neighbourhood perfect
GraphClass.note:
A neighbourhood cover of a graph $G$ is a set $S$ of vertices such that every edge of $G$ lies in $N[v]$ for some $v\in S$.
The neighbourhood cover number $\kappa_N(G)$ is the smallest cardinality of a neighbourhood cover of $G$.
Two edges of $G$ are said to be neighbourhood independent if there is no vertex $v$ such both edges lie in $N[v]$.
The neighbourhood independence number $\alpha_N(G)$ is the largest number of pairwise neighbourhood independent edges.
A graph is gc_131 if for each induced subgraph $$H: $\kappa_N(H) = \alpha_N(H)$.

GraphClass.name: circle
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_132 graph if it is the intersection graph of chords in a circle.

Let the local complement G*v result from G by complementing G[N(v)]. Two graphs are said to be locally equivalent if one results from the other by a series of local complements. Note that this is an equivalence relation. A graph G is a gc_132 graph iff no graph locally equivalent to G has an induced subgraph isomorphic to W_5,BW_3 or W_7 ref_140.

algo.name: Independent set
algo.note: where \alpha is the size of a maximum independent set and d is the density of the graph.

GraphClass.name: circular arc
GraphClass.note: A gc_133 graph is the intersection graph of arcs of a circle.
Characterize gc_133 graphs by forbidden induced subgraphs ref_1404.
Give an algorithm for finding a certificate for a graph not to be a gc_133 graph ref_1404.
Characterize gc_133 graphs that admit a model where the arcs have to most two sizes ref_1404.
Characterize circular arc bigraphs (see gc_167) ref_1404.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Where l is the minimum number of arcs passing through a given point on the circle.ref_995

GraphClass.name: circular permutation
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_135 if it has an intersection model consisting of paths between two concentric circles, such that no two paths intersect in more than one point.

GraphClass.name: containment graphs of circular arcs
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_136 if it has a containment model consisting of arcs on a circle (i.e. two vertices are adjacent if one of the corresponding arcs is contained in the other one).

GraphClass.name: Hamiltonian hereditary
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_138 if every connected induced subgraph has a Hamiltonian path (i.e. a path that visits every vertex exactly once).

GraphClass.name: clique
GraphClass.note:
The clique graph of a graph G is the intersection graph of the maximal complete subgraphs (cliques) in G.
A graph is a gc_141 graph if it is the clique graph of some graph.
A graph G is a gc_141 graph if there is a family of complete subgraphs of G that covers all edges of G and has the Helly property (see gc_105).

GraphClass.name: clique separable
GraphClass.note:
Call a graph primitive if it has no clique cutset. Then:
A graph G is gc_142 if every primitive induced subgraph of G is either complete k-partite or can be partitioned into a connected bipartite graph A and a clique B such that there is a join between A and B.

GraphClass.name: preperfect
GraphClass.note:
A vertex x predominates a vertex y if either they are adjacent and every maximal clique containing y also contains x, or they are non-adjacent and every maximal independent set containing x also contains y.
A graph is gc_143 (or predomination perfect) if every induced subgraph has a predominating vertex.

algo.name: Independent set
algo.note: See also ref_425.

GraphClass.name: absolutely perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_146 if every induced subgraph H has an independent set meeting all mininal vertex sets of H that are dominating \co{H}.
A graph is a gc_147 if it is the intersection graph of curves from a line to a parallel line.

GraphClass.name: quasi--parity
GraphClass.note:
Two vertices form an even pair if all chordless paths between them have even length.
A graph is gc_150 if for every induced subgraph H, either H or \co{H} has an even pair.

GraphClass.name: cograph
GraphClass.note:
G is a gc_151 (short for complement-reducible graph) if one of the following equivalent conditions hold:
G can be constructed from isolated vertices by disjoint union and join operations.
G is the disjoint union of gc_80 graphs with diameter at most 2.
in every induced subgraph H of G, the intersection of any maximal clique and any maximal independent set contains precisely one vertex.
Every nontrivial induced subgraph of G has at least one pair of twins (two vertices with the same neighbourhoods).
The complement of every nontrivial connected induced subgraph of G is disconnected.
Every connected induced subgraph of G has diameter at most 2.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of series--parallel posets
GraphClass.note:
The parallel composition of two posets is their disjoint union. The series composition P*Q of two posets P and Q has as elements the union of the elements of P and Q, and u<v in P*Q if either u<v in P or u<v in Q or u is in P and v is in Q (i.e. every element in P is smaller than every element in Q).
A series-parallel poset can be composed from single elements by repeated application of series and/or parallel composition.

GraphClass.name: cograph contraction
GraphClass.note: A gc_154 is formed from a gc_151 by contracting some disjoint independent sets and then creating a join between all contracted vertices.
A graph G is a gc_154 iff it has a clique Q such that every induced P_4 in G has a midpoint in Q and every induced P_5 in the complement of G has both endpoints in Q.

GraphClass.name: tree--perfect
GraphClass.note:
The P_4-structureref_206 of a graph G is a hypergraph having the the node of G as its vertex set and all 4-element vertex sets inducing a P_4 in G as its hyperedges.
A graph is gc_155 iff it has the P_4-structure of a gc_342.

algo.name: Cliquewidth
algo.note: See gc_3

algo.name: Cliquewidth
algo.note: See gc_234.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of semiorders
comparability graphs of dimension 3 posets
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_160 if it is the gc_72 graph of a poset of dimension 3. (The dimension of a poset P is the minimal number of linear extension of P whose intersection is P.)

GraphClass.name: containment graph of circles
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_161 if it has a containment model consisting of circles (disks) in 2 dimensional space (i.e. two vertices are adjacent if one of the corresponding circles is contained in the other one).

GraphClass.name: containment graphs
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_163 if it has a model consisting of objects space such that two vertices are adjacent if one of the corresponding objects is contained in the other one.

GraphClass.name: superperfect
GraphClass.note:
Let w be a non-negative weighting of the vertices of a graph G. An interval coloring of (G,w) maps each vertex v onto an open interval Iv with length w(v) of the real line, such that adjacent vertices are mapped to disjoint intervals.The interval coloring number \chiint(G,w) is the minimum length of the union of all Iv's over all interval colorings.
A graph is gc_164 if for every non-negative weighting w \chiint(G,w) = \omega(G,w), where \omega is the maximum clique weight.

GraphClass.name: interval bigraph
GraphClass.note: A gc_69 graph B=(X,Y,E) is an gc_167 if every vertex can be assigned an interval on the real line such that for all x \in X and y \in Y: xy \in E iff the corresponding intervals intersect.

A collection of sets U is consecutively orderable if the sets can be indexed U1,..,Un, such that for all i <= j <= k, whenever x is in Ui and in Uk, then x is in Uj.
A gc_69 graph G is an gc_167 if there exists a set of consecutively orderable complete bipartite graphs that cover the edges of G.
Characterize gc_167 graphs by forbidden induced subgraphs ref_1405.

GraphClass.name: tolerance
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_169 graph if every vertex v can be assigned a closed interval Iv on the real line and a tolerance tv such that x and y are adjacent iff |Ix \cap Iy| >= min{tx, ty}.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: ref_1497 This is optimal

algo.name: Colourability
algo.note: ref_1498 This is optimal

algo.name: Clique
algo.note: ref_1498 This is optimal

GraphClass.name: Dilworth 3
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_173 if it has Dilworth number 3.

GraphClass.name: Dilworth 4
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_174 if it has Dilworth number 4.

GraphClass.name: directed path
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_175 if it has an intersection model consisting of directed paths in a rooted directed tree.

Let G = (V,E) be a graph and K be the set of all maximal cliques of G. For each vertex v of G, let Kv be the set of cliques of K containing v. Then G is a gc_175 iff there exists a rooted directed tree T with the vertex set K, such that for every v in V, the subtree of T induced on Kv is a directed path in T.

GraphClass.name: cop--win
GraphClass.note:
An ordering v1...vn of the vertices of a graph is a cop-win ordering (or dismantling ordering) if for each i<n there is a j>i such that Ni[vi] \subseteq Ni[vj].
A graph is gc_176 if it has a cop-win ordering.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: with $a$ the arboricity of the graph; from ref_1643 and ref_1644

GraphClass.name: (5,2)--crossing--chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_177 if every cycle of at least 5 nodes has at least 2 crossing chords. Two chords uv, xy are crossing if the order in C of the endpoints is (u,x,v,y).

GraphClass.name: domino
GraphClass.note: G is a gc_179 graph if every vertex of G is contained in at most two maximal cliques of G.

GraphClass.name: doubly chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_181 if it is gc_183.

GraphClass.name: Helly chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_184 if it is gc_204.

GraphClass.name: dually chordal
GraphClass.note:
A vertex u in N[v] is a maximum neighbour of v if for all w in N[v]: N[w] \subseteq N[u]. A vertex ordering v1...vn is a maximumneighbourhood ordering if for each i<n vi has a maximum neighbour in Gi.
A graph is gc_185 if it has a maximum neighbourhood ordering.
A graph G is gc_185 iff there is a spanning tree T of G, such that every maximal clique of G induces a subtree in T.

A disk D(v,k) in G is the set of vertices that have distance at most k to v.
A graph G is gc_185 iff there is a spanning tree T of G, such that every disk of G induces a subtree in T.

GraphClass.name: homogeneously orderable
GraphClass.note:
A vertex v of G is h-extremal if D2(v) contains a dominating set that is proper homogeneous (a non-trivial module) in G.
A vertex ordering v1,..,vn is a homogeneous elimination ordering if for every i, vi is h-extremal in G[vi...vn].
G is gc_187 if it has homogeneous elimination ordering.

GraphClass.name: semi--$P_4$--sparse
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_190 iff it is gc_308 free.

GraphClass.name: $i$--triangulated
GraphClass.note: A synonym for gc_73.

GraphClass.name: (5,2)--odd--noncrossing--chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_192 if every cycle of odd length at least 5 has at least 2 noncrossing chords.

GraphClass.name: Meyniel
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_194 if every cycle of odd length at least 5 has at least 2 chords.

An even pair in a graph is a pair of non-adjacent vertices x, y such that every chordless path has an even number of edges.
A graph is gc_194 if for every connected induced subgraph H that is not a complete graph, all vertices are part of an even pair in H.

GraphClass.name: bigeodetic
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_195 if every pair of vertices has at most 2 paths of minimum length between them.

GraphClass.name: weakly geodetic
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_196 if for every pair of vertices of distance 2 there is a unique common neighbour of them.

GraphClass.name: quasitriangulated
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_197 if it has an elimination ordering v1,..,vn such that vi is simplicial in Gi or in \overline{Gi}.

A graph is latticed if every vertex belongs to some cycle and some co-cycle, both of length at least 4.
A graph G is gc_197 if no induced subgraph of G is latticed.

GraphClass.name: Halin
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_198 graph if it is formed by embedding a gc_342 having no degree-2 vertices in the plane and connecting its leaves by a cycle that crosses none of its edges.

GraphClass.name: partial 3--tree
GraphClass.note: See gc_595

GraphClass.name: 3--Helly
GraphClass.note: G is a gc_201 graph if every 3 pairwise intersecting disks have a non-empty intersection.

GraphClass.name: neighbourhood--Helly
GraphClass.note:
The neighbourhood hypergraph of G has V(G) has its vertices and the closed neighbourhoods N[v], v in V(G), as its edge sets.
A graph is gc_202 if its neighbourhood hypergraph has the Helly property.

GraphClass.name: pseudo--modular
GraphClass.note: G is gc_203 if every metric triangle has size at most 1.

GraphClass.name: Helly circular arc
GraphClass.note: G is a gc_205 graph if there is a circular arc representation of G that satisfies the Helly property.
G is a gc_205 graph if it admits a clique matrix (cliques in rows, vertices in columns) that has the circular consecutive one property for columns.

An obstacle is a graph H, containing a clique Q on at least 3 vertices, admitting a circular ordering v1..vq on its vertices, where each edge vivi+1 satisfies
there is a vertex wi outside Q such that wi is adjacent to all vertices in Q except for vi, vi+1; or
there is an edge uizi outside Q such that li is adjacent to all vertices in Q except for vi and zi is adjacent to all vertices in Q except for vi+1.
G is a gc_205 graph if it is a gc_133 graph and does not contain an obstacle as an induced subgraph.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: a(x,y) is the (very slowly growing) functional inverse of the Ackermann function

GraphClass.name: median
GraphClass.note: Let $I(x,y)$ be the set of all vertices on all shortest paths between $x$ and $y$. G is gc_211 if for all vertices $x,y,z$: $I(x,y) \cap I(x,z) \cap I(y,z) = 1$.

GraphClass.name: $N^*$--perfect
GraphClass.note:
Define a preorder <v of the nodes of a graph by: x<vy iff N'(x) \subseteq N[y], where N'(x) is the set of nodes at distance 1 or 2 from x.
A graph is gc_215 if every ordering v1,...,vn such that i < j iff vi >v vj and not vj >v vi is a perfect order.

GraphClass.name: murky
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_218 if it is gc_273.

GraphClass.name: $V$--perfect
GraphClass.note:
An ordering <o of the nodes of a graph is a vicinal preoder if for all vertices x, y: x<oy iff N(x) \subseteq N[y].
A graph is gc_220 if every ordering v1,...,vn such that i < j iff vi >o vj and not vj >o vi is a perfect order.

GraphClass.name: isometric--HH--free
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_221 it doesn't contain a house or hole as isometric subgraph.

GraphClass.name: weakly modular
GraphClass.note:
The triangle condition: For every three vertices u,v,w with 1 = d(v,w) < d(u,v) = d(u,w), there is a common neighour x of v and w such that d(u,x) = d(u,v) + 1.
The quadrangle condition: For every four vertices, u,v,w,z with d(v,z) = d(w,z) = 1 and d(u,v) = d(u,w) = d(u,z) - 1, there is a common neighbour x of v and w such that d(u,x) = d(u,v) - 1.
A graph is gc_222 if its distance metric fulfills the triangle and quadrangle conditions.

The interval I(u,v) contains all vertices that lie on a shortest path from u to v. Three vertices u,v,w form a metric triangle if the interval I(u,v), I(v,w) and I(w,u) pairwise intersect only in the common end vertices.
A graph is gc_222 if for every metric triangle u,v,w all vertices of I(v,w) are at the same distance k=d(u,v) from u.

GraphClass.name: maxibrittle
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_225 if every induced subgraph of G has no P_4 having a vertex of maximum degree as an endpoint and no P_4 having a vertex of minimum degree as an endpoint.

GraphClass.name: HH--free
GraphClass.note:
A 2-pair in a graph is a pair of non-adjacent vertices x, y such that every chordless path has exactly two edges.
A graph is gc_228 if for every connected induced subgraph H that is not a complete graph, all vertices are part of a 2-pair in H.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: a(x,y) is the (very slowly growing) functional inverse of the Ackermann function

GraphClass.name: (5,2)--chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_230 if every cycle of length at least 5 has at least 2 chords.

GraphClass.name: interval
GraphClass.note: A graph is an gc_234 graph if it has an intersection model consisting of intervals on a straight line.

Even though the weighted clique and colourability problems are polynomial time solvable on both gc_234 and gc_157 graphs, the weighted clique partitioning problem [PCliqW] is NP-hard for gc_234 graphs ref_1484.

algo.name: Hamiltonian cycle
algo.note: ref_1532 if the interval representation is given

algo.name: Hamiltonian path
algo.note: ref_1532 if the interval representation is given

GraphClass.name: boxicity 1
GraphClass.note: A graph has gc_236 if it has an intersection model consisting of axis-parallel boxes in 1-dimensional space.

GraphClass.name: boxicity 2
GraphClass.note: A graph has gc_239 if it has an intersection model consisting of axis-parallel boxes (i.e. rectangles) in 2-dimensional space.

algo.name: Clique
algo.note: Assuming the intersection model is given.

GraphClass.name: PI
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_240 (Point-Interval) graph if it has an intersection model consisting of triangle between two lines L and M such that every triangle a,b,c has a on L and bc on M.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: Recognition is in NP ref_1496.

GraphClass.name: threshold signed
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_246 if there are positive real numbers S,T (the thresholds) and for every vertex v there is a real weight av <=S,T such that: vw is an edge iff either |av + aw| >= S or |av - aw| >= T.

algo.name: Domination
algo.note: From gc_234 and gc_157.

GraphClass.name: line
GraphClass.note:
The line graph (E,E') of G = (V,E) has edges (e,f) if e\cap f isn't empty in G.
A graph is a gc_249 graph if it is the line graph of some graph.
A graph G is a gc_249 graph if the edges of G can be partitioned into maximal complete subgraphs such that no vertex lies in more than two of the subgraphs.

A triangle T of a graph G is called odd if there is a vertex of G that is adjacent to an odd number of vertices of T.
A graph G is a gc_249 graph if G is gc_62 and if two odd triangles have a common edge, then the subgraph induced by their vertices is a K_4.

GraphClass.name: locally perfect
GraphClass.note:
Let C be a colouring of of the vertices G such that no two neighbouring vertices have the same colour. Let F(v,C) be the number of colours appearing in N(v). C is locally perfect if for every vertex v: F(v,C) = \omega(N(v)), where \omega(S) is the size of a maximum clique in S.
A graph is gc_254 if every induced subgraph has a locally perfect colouring.

GraphClass.name: matrogenic
GraphClass.note: A set W of vertices of G = (V,E) is threshold independent if G[W] is a gc_328 graph. Let IV denote the family of threshold independent vertex sets. Then G is gc_255 if (V,IV) is a matroid.

GraphClass.name: unigraph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_256 if it is determined by its degree sequence up to isomorphism.

GraphClass.name: matroidal
GraphClass.note: A set F of edges of G = (V,E) is threshold independent if G[F] is a gc_328 graph. Let IE denote the family of threshold independent edge sets. Then G is gc_257 if (E,IE) is a matroid.

GraphClass.name: Matula perfect
GraphClass.note:
A graph is gc_259 if every vertex ordering < such that
x < y whenever degH(x) >= degH(y) and H is the subgraph induced by all z such that z <= y
is perfect.

GraphClass.name: Hilbertian
GraphClass.note: Let I(x,y) be the set of all vertices on all shortest paths between x and y. G is gc_261 if for all vertices x,y,z: I(x,y) contains a unique vertex nearest to z.

GraphClass.name: pseudo--median
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_262 if for every triple of vertices u,v,w either there exists a unique vertex on shortest paths between each pair of them (if their mutual distances sum up to an even number), or there exists a unique triangle whose edges lie on a shortest paths between the three pairs of u,v,w (if the distance sum is odd).
A graph is gc_262 if the following condition holds for all triples of vertices u,v,w: if 1<=d(v,w)<=2 and d(u,v) = d(u,w) = k>=2 then there is a unique vertex x adjacent to v and w with d(u,x)=k-1.

GraphClass.name: quasi--median
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_263 if every interval in G induces a gc_211 graph and for any three vertices u,v,w: I(u,v) \cap I(u,w) = {u} implies that d(v,w) >= max( d(u,v), d(u,w) ).

GraphClass.name: (5,2)--odd--chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_264 if every odd cycle of length at least 5 has at least 2 chords.

GraphClass.name: very strongly perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_265 if for every induced subgraph H, every vertex of H belongs to an independent set of H meeting all maximal cliques of H.

GraphClass.name: perfectly contractile
GraphClass.note:
Two vertices form an even pair if all chordless paths between them have even length.
A graph is gc_266 if for all induced subgraphs H there is a sequence H=H0,...,Hk such that Hk is a clique and Hi+1 is obtained from Hi by contracting an even pair.

GraphClass.name: strongly perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_267 if every induced subgraph H has an independent set meeting all maximal cliques of H.

GraphClass.name: minimally imperfect
GraphClass.note:
A graph is gc_270 if it is not gc_56 and every induced subgraph is gc_56.
These are precisely the odd (anti)-holes ref_1128.

GraphClass.name: partitionable
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_271 if there are a,w such that G has aw+1 vertices and for each vertex v of G: G-v admits a partition into a cliques of size w and a partition into w independent sets of size a.

GraphClass.name: multitolerance
GraphClass.note: For an interval I = [l,r] on the real line and lt,rt \in I, define I(lt,rt) as the set of all intervals [l+(rt-l)x, lt+(r-lt)x] for all 0<=x<=1. The set of tolerance intervals for I is either I(lt,rt) or the (infinite) real line. A graph is a gc_272 graph if every vertex v can be assigned a closed interval Iv on the real line and a set Tv of tolerance intervals such that x and y are adjacent iff either there is a t in Tx such that t \subseteq Iy or there is a t in Ty such that t \subseteq Ix.

algo.name: Clique
algo.note: ref_1497 This is optimal

GraphClass.name: Berge
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_274 if it is gc_597.

GraphClass.name: series--parallel
GraphClass.note:
Let G be a multigraph. Two edge e, f in G are confluent if there are no cycles C, D in G, such that C meets e and f in the same direction, but D meets e and f in the opposite direction.
G is gc_275 if every pair of edges is confluent.

The S operation entails subdividing an edge by a new vertex (replacing an edge by two edges in series).
The P operation entails replacing an edge by two edges in parallel.
Let G be a multigraph. G is gc_275 if its 2-connected components can be generated from a loop with S and P operations.

The S operation entails deleting a vertex of degree 2 and adding a new edge between its neighbours.
The P operation entails deleting an edge parallel to another edge.
Let G be a multigraph. G is gc_275 if its 2-connected components can be reduced to a loop with S and P operations.

GraphClass.name: (5,2)--odd--crossing--chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_276 if every odd cycle C of length at least 5 has at least 2 crossing chords. Two chords uv, xy are crossing if the order in C of the endpoints is (u,x,v,y).

GraphClass.name: unbreakable
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_277 if neither G nor its complement have a star-cutset. A star-cutset is a cutset that contains a vertex that is adjacent to all other vertices of the cutset.
A graph G is gc_278 iff each component of G is gc_69 or complete multipartite.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: By the characterization.

algo.name: Colourability
algo.note: By the characterization.

GraphClass.name: ${\cal C}(G)$--perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_279 if for every subgraph H we have for the hypergraph H' formed by all cliques in H that alpha(H') = kappa(H'), where alpha is the packing number (max. vertex set such that every hyperedge contains at most one vertex from the set) and kappa the covering number (min. edge set that contains all vertices).

GraphClass.name: perfectly 1--transversable
GraphClass.note:
An induced subgraph H of G is an i-transversal if \omega(H)=i and \omega(G-H) = \omega(G)-i, where \omega is the maximum clique size.
A graph G is perfectly i-transversable if each induced subgraph H of G admits a min(\omega(H), i)-transversal of H.

GraphClass.name: kernel solvable
GraphClass.note:
A superorientation of a graph G=(V,E) is an orientation of all edges uv, where both u->v and v->u may occur simultaneously.
Let D=(V,A) be a (super)oriented graph. S\subseteq V is a kernel of D if it is both independent, i.e. no vertex of S has a successor in S, and absorbant, i.e. every vertex outside S has a successor in S.
A graph D is gc_281 if for every superorientation D of G for which every clique has a kernel, D itself has a kernel.

GraphClass.name: normal
GraphClass.note:
A graph G is gc_282 if there exists families C and S of sets of vertices such that
for all c in C and s in S: c\cap s is non-empty,
every member of C induces a clique in G and every member of S induces an independent set in G,
every vertex of G is obtainable as an intersection of members of C and S.

GraphClass.name: circle graph with equator
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_285 if it is a gc_132 that admits an additional chord (the equator) that intersects every other chord.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of dimension 2 posets
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_287 if it is the gc_72 of a poset of dimension 2 (The dimension of a poset P is the minimal number of linear extension of P whose intersection is P.)

GraphClass.name: containment graph of intervals
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_288 if it has a containment model consisting of intervals on a line (i.e. two vertices are adjacent if one of the corresponding intervals is contained in the other one).

GraphClass.name: PI$^*$
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_290 graph if it has an intersection model consisting of triangles between two lines.

GraphClass.name: genus 0
GraphClass.note: The genus of a graph is the smallest genus of a surface in which G can be embedded without crossings.

GraphClass.name: ${\cal P}_3$--perfect
GraphClass.note:
Let chi'(G) be the minimum size of a partition of G into K_3-free subgraphs and let omega'(G) be the maximum of chi'(C) over all cliques C of G.
A graph is gc_292 if for each induced subgraph H of G: chi'(H) = omega'(H).

GraphClass.name: toroidal
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_293 if it can be embedded in the torus without crossings.

GraphClass.name: power--chordal
GraphClass.note:
The k-th power of a graph G is a graph on the same vertex set as G, where a pair of vertices is connected by an edge if they have distance at most k in G.
A graph is gc_294 if all its powers are gc_32.

GraphClass.name: clique--chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_296 if the gc_249 graph of its gc_141 graph is chordal.

GraphClass.name: proper circular arc
GraphClass.note: A gc_297 graph is a gc_133 graph that has an intersection model in which no arc properly contains another.

GraphClass.name: proper interval
GraphClass.note: A gc_298 graph is an gc_234 graph that has an intersection model in which no interval properly contains another.

algo.name: Hamiltonian cycle
algo.note: ref_1531 if the interval representation is given

GraphClass.name: unit interval
GraphClass.note: A gc_299 graph is an gc_234 graph that has an intersection model in which every interval has unit length.

GraphClass.name: astral triple--free
GraphClass.note:
Three vertices are an astral triple if for every pair of them there is a path connecting the two vertices that contains neither the third vertex nor two consecutive vertices that are neighbours of the third vertex.
A graph is gc_302 if it does not contain an astral triple.

GraphClass.name: unit circular arc
GraphClass.note: A gc_304 graph is a gc_133 graph that has an intersection model in which every arc has unit length.

GraphClass.name: proper tolerance
GraphClass.note: A gc_305 is a gc_169 graph in which no interval contains another interval.

GraphClass.name: $K_4$--minor--free
GraphClass.note:
G is a minor of H if G can be obtained from H be a series of vertex deletions, edge deletions and/or edge contractions (replacing two adjacent vertices u,v by a vertex that is adjacent to all neighbours of u or v).
A graph G is gc_309 if K_4 isn't a minor of G.

GraphClass.name: short--chorded
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_311 if every odd hole has a short chord, i.e. a chord joining two vertices of distance 2 in the cycle.

GraphClass.name: polar
GraphClass.note: A gc_314 graph is a graph G whose vertex set can be partitioned into two sets A and B, such that A induces a subgraph of the complement of G and B induces a subgraph of G all of whose connected components are complete graphs.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: NP-Complete for any fixed >=2 maximum cardinality of a connected component of G(B).

GraphClass.name: strict 2--threshold
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_316 graph if its edge-set can be partitioned into two threshold graphs A and B such that every triangle of G is a triangle of A or a triangle of B.

GraphClass.name: generalized strongly chordal
GraphClass.note: A synonym for gc_320.

GraphClass.name: strongly orderable
GraphClass.note:
A vertex ordering of a graph G is a strong ordering if for all i<j, k<l: if vivk, vivl, vjvk are edges, then vjvl is an edge.
Note that a strong ordering is not necessarily a perfect elimination ordering.
A graph is gc_320 if it admits a strong ordering.

GraphClass.name: strong tree--cograph
GraphClass.note: A gc_323 is a gc_321 if the gc_323s used in the disjoint union are pairwise nonisomorphic.

GraphClass.name: Birkhoff
GraphClass.note: A graph with adjacency matrix A is a gc_322 if every double stochastic matrix X for which XAX-1 = A is a convex sum of automorphisms of A.

GraphClass.name: tree--cograph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_323 if it can be constructed from trees by disjoint union and complement operations.

algo.name: Cliquewidth
algo.note: From the decomposition tree.

algo.name: Cliquewidth expression
algo.note: From the decomposition tree.

GraphClass.name: superfragile
GraphClass.note:
Elimination rule 1: if x does not appear as an endpoint in an induced P_3 then x may be removed.
Elimination rule 2: if x does not appear as a midpoint in an induced P_3 then x may be removed.
A graph is gc_325 if it has an elimination order w.r.t. the above rules, such that at every stage every vertex is eligible for elimination.
A graph G is gc_325 iff in every induced subgraph of G no vertex is both a midpoint of an induced P_3 and an endpoint of an induced P_3.

GraphClass.name: trivially perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_327 if for every induced subgraph H, alpha(H) = |C(H)|, where alpha is the size of the largest independent set and C is the set of all maximal cliques.

GraphClass.name: threshold
GraphClass.note:
The following are equivalent definitions of the threshold dimension of a graph:
Let G be a graph with nodes v1...vn. The characteristic vector x of X\subseteq V has xi = 1 if vi in X and 0 otherwise. The treshold dimension \theta(G) if the minimum number k of linear inequalities aj1x1 + ... + ajnxn <= tj (1<=j<= k) such that X is an independent set iff its characteristic vector x satisfies this system of inequalities.
The treshold dimension of a graph (V,E) is the minimum number k of threshold graphs (V,Ei) such that E equals the union of all Ei.
A graph is a gc_328 graph iff its threshold dimension is at most 1.
A graph is a gc_328 graph if there is a real number S (the threshold) and for every vertex v there is a real weight av such that: vw is an edge iff av + aw >= S.
A graph is a gc_328 graph if it can constructed from the empty graph by repeatedly adding either an isolated vertex or a dominating vertex.

GraphClass.name: Dilworth 1
GraphClass.note:
Two vertices x and y are said to be comparable if either N(y) \subseteq N[x] or N(x) \subseteq N[y].
The Dilworth number of a graph is the largest number of pairwise incomparable vertices of the graph.
A graph is a gc_330 if it has Dilworth number 1.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of threshold orders
GraphClass.note: A threshold order is a partial order P on a set V, with weightfunction w on V and a threshold t such that C is a maximal chain of P iff the sum of the weights of the nodes in C is at most t.

GraphClass.name: Dilworth 2
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_335 if it has Dilworth number 2.

GraphClass.name: threshold tolerance
GraphClass.note: A graph (V,E) is a gc_336 is there are real-valued functions w and t on V such that xy is an edge iff w(x)+w(y) >= min(t(x), t(y)).
A graph is a gc_336 if there are real-valued weight functions a and b on V such that xy is an edge iff a(x) <= b(y) and a(y) <= b(x).

GraphClass.name: genus 1
GraphClass.note: The genus of a graph is the smallest genus of a surface in which G can be embedded without crossings.

GraphClass.name: bounded multitolerance
GraphClass.note: A gc_272 graph is a gc_341 graph if it doesn't contain any vertex with the real line as its set of tolerance intervals.

GraphClass.name: tree
GraphClass.note: A gc_342 is a connected acyclic graph. A disconnect acyclic graph (i.e. every connected component is a tree) is a forest.

algo.name: Domination
algo.note: Obvious.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of arborescence orders
GraphClass.note: A partial order (V,<) is an arborescence order if for all x in V the set {y|y<x} is linearly ordered.

GraphClass.name: intersection graph of nested intervals
GraphClass.note: A graph is an gc_347 if it is an gc_234 graph with a model in which no interval partially overlaps another interval.

GraphClass.name: $p$--connected
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_348 if for every partition of V(G) into X and Y there is a crossing P_4 between X and Y, i.e. a P_4 containing vertices from both X and Y.

A p-chain connecting two vertices x and y is a sequence of distinct vertices v1...vk such that x = v1, y = vk and for all i <= k-3 the set {vi, vi+1, vi+2, vi+3} induces a P_4.
A graph G is gc_348 if every pair of vertices is connected by a p-chain.

GraphClass.name: unit tolerance
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_349 if it is a gc_169 in which every interval is of unit length.

GraphClass.name: Welsh--Powell perfect
GraphClass.note:
A graph is gc_350 if every vertex ordering < such that
x < y whenever degG(x) >= degG(y)
is perfect.

GraphClass.name: wing--triangulated
GraphClass.note:
For a graph $G$ the graph $W(G)$ having all edges of $G$ as its vertices, two edges of $G$ being adjacent in $W(G)$ if they are the nonincident edges (called wings) of an induced path on four vertices in $G$, is called the wing-graph of G.
A graph G is gc_352 if W(G) is gc_945.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: with $a$ the arboricity of the graph ref_1643

GraphClass.note: Every connected component of a gc_357 graph is gc_371 or complete multipartite.

GraphClass.name: (6,1)--chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_365 if every cycle of length at least 6 has at least 1 chord.

GraphClass.name: X--conformal
GraphClass.note: Let B=(X,Y,E) be a bipartite graph. B is gc_368 if for every S $\subseteq$ Y with the property that all nodes of S have pairwise distance 2, there is a node x in X such that S $\subseteq$ N(x).

GraphClass.name: X--chordal
GraphClass.note: Let B=(X,Y,E) be a bipartite graph. B is gc_369 if for cycle C in B of length at least 8, there is a node x in X that is adjacent to at leeast two nodes in C whose distance in C is at least 4 (that is, x is a bridge node).

GraphClass.name: (6,2)--chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_370 if every cycle of length at least 6 has at least 2 chords.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of posets of interval dimension 2
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_377 if it is the gc_72 of a poset of interval dimension 2.
For connected graphs, this class is equivalent to gc_379. In ref_68 equivalence is claimed falsely for unconnected graphs as well, see the note at ref_68.

GraphClass.name: thick tree
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_383 if it is gc_32 and every two separators are either equal or disjoint.

GraphClass.name: AC
GraphClass.note: A graph is an gc_384 graph if it is chordal and every vertex belong to at most 2 maximal cliques.
Largest subclass of sun-free that is closed under complementation

GraphClass.name: unit disk
GraphClass.note: A gc_389 graph is a gc_414 graph with an intersection model consisting of disks of unit size.
Many problems that are NP-complete in general remain NP-complete on this class. See e.g. ref_229.

algo.name: Clique
algo.note: Assuming the positions of the disks are given ref_229.

GraphClass.name: interval filament
GraphClass.note:
Let I be a collection of intervals on a line L. In the plane above L, construct to each interval i\in I a curve ci connecting its two endpoints, such that ci remains within the limits of i. The curves ci are called interval filaments.
A graph is an gc_390 graph if it has an intersection model consisting of interval filaments.
A graph is an gc_390 if it is the intersection graph of continuous non-negative functions defined on closed intervals with zero-values on their endpoints.

algo.name: Cliquewidth
algo.note: See gc_350.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: Finite forbidden subgraph characterization.

GraphClass.note: Every connected gc_396 graph has a dominating clique or a dominating P_3 ref_42.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: trivial

GraphClass.name: planar of maximum degree 3
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_412 if it is gc_43 and every vertex has degree at most 3.

GraphClass.name: disk
GraphClass.note: A gc_414 graph is the intersection graph of disks in two-dimensional space.

GraphClass.name: well covered
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_415 if every maximal independent set is a maximum independent set.

algo.name: Independent set
algo.note: trivial

GraphClass.name: visibility
GraphClass.note:
Let P be a simple polygon in standard position. The visibility graph of P has vertices corresponding to the extreme points of P. Two vertices are adjacent if either they are consecutive extreme points of P, or the line between them is entirely contained in P.
A graph is a gc_419 graph if it is the visibility graph of some polygon.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Because for all v: G[\co{N}(v)] is P_4-free

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Algorithm for (P_5,K_{m,m})-free (fixed m) ref_1118

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Algorithm for (P_5,K_{m,m})-free (fixed m) ref_1118

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Algorithm for (P_5,K_{m,m})-free (fixed m) ref_1118

GraphClass.name: subtree overlap
GraphClass.note: A graph G=(V,E) is a gc_434 if every node x,y in V can be assigned a subtree of a tree I such that x and y are adjacent iff their corresponding subtrees overlap (i.e. the subtrees intersect, but neither one contains the other one).

GraphClass.name: partial grid
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_440 iff it is an arbitrary subgraph (not necessarily induced) of a gc_464.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: with $a$ the arboricity of the graph ref_1643

GraphClass.name: bipartite chain
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_442 graph iff it is gc_69 and for each color class the neighbourhoods of the nodes in that color class can be ordered linearly w.r.t. inclusion (subset or equal).
Sometimes called gc_452.

GraphClass.name: bi-cograph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_444 iff it is a gc_69 graph that can be reduced to isolated vertices by recursively bi-complementing the edge set of all connected bipartite subgraphs, where the bi-complement of (X,Y,E) is (X,Y, X\times Y - E).

GraphClass.name: bisplit
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_452 iff it can be partitioned in an independent set and a bi-clique.
Attention: gc_442 graphs are sometimes also called gc_452.

GraphClass.name: tripartite
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_453 iff it can be partitioned in 3 independent sets.

algo.name: Colourability
algo.note: Trivial. Note that finding an actual colour assignment is NP-complete ref_1425.

GraphClass.name: weak bisplit
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_457 iff it has an independent set X such that every connected component of G-X is a biclique.
Attention: gc_446 graphs are sometimes also called gc_457.

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--simplicial
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_459 if it admits an acyclic orientation in which each induced P_4 is either of the type: o<-o->o->o or of the type o->o->o->o

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--indifference
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_460 if it admits an acyclic orientation in which each induced P_4 is of the type: o->o->o->o

GraphClass.name: k-polygon
GraphClass.note: A gc_462 graph is the intersection graph of chords in a k-polygon.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: Assuming the input is a gc_132 graph.ref_353

GraphClass.name: grid
GraphClass.note: An n\times m gc_464 is the cartesian product of P_n and P_m.

algo.name: Treewidth
algo.note: The treewidth of a n x m grid is min(n, m) ref_1411

GraphClass.name: split-perfect
GraphClass.note:
The P_4-structureref_206 of a graph G is a hypergraph having the the node of G as its vertex set and all 4-element vertex sets inducing a P_4 in G as its hyperedges.
A graph is gc_465 iff it has the P_4-structure of a gc_39 graph.

algo.name: Domination
algo.note: Assuming a square embedding of the graph is given; finding this is an open problem.

GraphClass.name: bounded treewidth
GraphClass.note:
A tree decomposition of a graph G=(V,E) is a pair ({Xi | i in I}, T = (I, F)) with {Xi | i in I} a family of subsets of V, one for each node in T, and T a tree such that
the union of all Xi, i in I equals V.
for all edges (v,w) in E, there exists i in I, such that v in Xi and w in Xi.
for all v in V: the set of nodes {i in I | v in Xi} forms a subtree of T
The width of the tree decomposition is max |Xi| - 1.
The treewidth of a graph is the minimum width over all possible tree decompositions of the graph.
A graph is of gc_470 if its treewidth is at most a given constant k.

GraphClass.name: 2-subdivision
GraphClass.note:
A 2-subdivision of a graph results from inserting 2 new vertices in every edge, that is from replacing each edge $uv$ with a P_4 $uxyv$.
A graph is a gc_472 if it is the 2-subdivision of some graph.

algo.name: Independent set
algo.note: From Poljak'sref_1111 construction (which is a 2-subdivision). See also ref_453

algo.name: Cliquewidth
algo.note: See gc_69.

GraphClass.note: Let G be gc_486 and U,U' a bipartition of its vertex set in two cliques. Then G is gc_487 iff the edges between U and U' can be bi-coloured in such a way that the edges of any induced C_4 have distinct colours.

Let G be a graph and let G* be the graph with V(G*) = E(G) and two vertices of G* are adjacent precisely when the endpoints of the corresponding edges of G induce a C_4 in G.
G is gc_487 iff both the complement of G and G* are gc_69.
If a graph is in gc_487, then it has a circular arc model with two points on the circle, such that every arc contains at least one of them.

GraphClass.name: (q,t)
GraphClass.note: G is a gc_488 if every set of at most q vertices induces at most t distinct P_4's.

GraphClass.name: (p,q)-colorable
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_500 iff it can be partitioned in p cliques and q independent sets.

GraphClass.name: partner-limited
GraphClass.note:
A partner of a P_4 A in G is a vertex v in G-A such that A+v induces at least two P_4s.
A graph G is gc_504 if any P_4 has at most two partners.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of posets of interval dimension 2, height 1
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_522 if it is the gc_72 of a poset of interval dimension 2, height 1.

algo.name: Cliquewidth
algo.note: See gc_522.

GraphClass.name: difference
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_524 if every vertex vi can be assigned a real number ai and there exists a positive real number T such that (a) |ai| < T for all i and (b) (vi, vj) in E <=> |ai-aj| >= T.
A gc_525 graph consists of disjoint cycles and paths.

GraphClass.name: F_n grid
GraphClass.note: An gc_526 is a modification of an $n\times n$ gc_464 which has unbounded cliquewidth. See ref_1176 for a precise definition; as an example, $F_4$ looks like this:

GraphClass.name: H_{n,q} grid
GraphClass.note: An gc_527 with $n\ge 4$ is a modification of an $n\times n$ gc_464 which has unbounded cliquewidth for any fixed $q\ge 2$. See ref_1176 for a precise definition; as an example, $H_{4,2}$ looks like this:

algo.name: Independent set
algo.note: Contains the gc_472 of graphs of max. degree 3. See also gc_412.

GraphClass.name: Raspail
GraphClass.note: Synonym for either gc_87 or gc_311 graphs.

GraphClass.name: spider graph
GraphClass.note: A graph is is a gc_536 if every vertex vi can be assigned a set Si of points on the circle such that vi and vj are adjacent iff there exist a,b in Si and x,y in Sj such that a<x<b<y or x<a<y<b.

GraphClass.name: $N^*$
GraphClass.note:
Define a preorder <v of the nodes of a graph by: x<vy iff N'(x) \subseteq N[y], where N'(x) is the set of nodes at distance 1 or 2 from x.
A graph is an gc_541 if in all induced subgraphs any two vertices are comparable with respect to <v.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: If a (P,N) partition is given, they can be recognized in O(V+E log V) time ref_1280 ref_1199

GraphClass.name: (6,1)-even-chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_546 if every even cycle of length at least 6 has at least 1 chord.
Confusion danger: The class gc_706 is sometimes also called gc_547.

GraphClass.name: domination perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_549 if for every induced subgraph H a minimum dominating set has the same cardinality as a minimum independent dominating set. Note that a set is independent dominating set iff it is maximal independent.

GraphClass.name: middle
GraphClass.note: The middle graph of G=(V,E) is the intersection graph of V\cup E. A graph is a gc_551 graph if it is the middle graph of some graph.

GraphClass.name: indifference
GraphClass.note:
A vertex order is an indifference order iff for every P_3 abc : a<b and b<c or a<b and b<a
A graph is an gc_555 graph if it admits an indifference order.
A graph is an gc_555 graph if it admits an acyclic orientation in which every P_3 is oriented as o->o->o.

GraphClass.name: chordal-perfect
GraphClass.note:
The P_4-structureref_206 of a graph G is a hypergraph having the the node of G as its vertex set and all 4-element vertex sets inducing a P_4 in G as its hyperedges.
A graph is gc_557 iff it has the P_4-structure of a gc_32 graph.

GraphClass.name: irredundance perfect
GraphClass.note:
A vertex x is said to be redundant in a vertex set X if N[x] - N[X\x] is empty. A set that contains no redundant vertices is irredundant. The irredundance number ir(G) of G is the minimum cardinality taken over all maximal irredundant vertex sets of G.
The cardinality of a minimum dominating set of G is called the domination number \gamma(G).
A graph is gc_560 if for every induced subgraph H: ir(H) = \gamma(H).

algo.name: Weighted clique
algo.note: The number of cliques is polynomially bounded ref_666.

GraphClass.name: weak dominating pair
GraphClass.note:
A pair of vertices in a graph is called a dominating pair if the vertex set of every path between these two vertices is a dominating set.
A graph is a gc_568 graph if it has a dominating pair.

GraphClass.name: diametral path
GraphClass.note:
A diametral path of a graph is a shortest path whose length is equal to the diameter of the graph.
A graph is a gc_569 if every connected induced subgraph has a dominating diametral path.

GraphClass.name: homogeneously representable
GraphClass.note: An gc_234 graph G is gc_571 if for every vertex v there is an interval representation of G such that v is represented by an end interval.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: From gc_437, gc_597 and gc_574.

GraphClass.name: reflexive
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_581 if for every node v there is an edge (v,v) (a loop).

GraphClass.name: $k$-tree, fixed $k$
GraphClass.note:
A complete graph on k nodes is a gc_594.
If G is a gc_594 and C is a k-clique of G, then the graph formed by adding a new vertex to G, and making it adjacent to all nodes of C is a gc_594.

GraphClass.name: partial $k$-tree, fixed $k$
GraphClass.note: G is a gc_595 if it is a spanning subgraph of a gc_594

GraphClass.name: interval regular
GraphClass.note: A connected graph is gc_600 if for any two vertices u, v the number of neighbours of u on all shortest (u,v)-paths equals d(u,v).

GraphClass.name: interval regular of diameter 2
GraphClass.note: A connected graph is gc_601 if every pair of nonadjacent vertices has exactly two paths of length 2 between them, i.e. has exactly two common neighbours.

GraphClass.name: bipartite tolerance
GraphClass.note: A gc_69 graph is a gc_602 graph if there is a tolerance t and a function f from vertices to real numbers such that xy is an edge iff |f(x) - f(y)| <= t.
Since this class is equal to gc_1013, but not equal to gc_1009, it would be more appropriate to call it bipartite bounded tolerance graphs.

GraphClass.name: D
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_604 if each induced subgraph contains a vertex x such that for any edge yz with y,z not neighbours of x, y dominates z or vice versa.

GraphClass.name: domishold
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_605 if there is a threshold S and every vertex v has a positive real weight w(v) such that U is a dominating set iff the sum of the weights of the vertices in U exceeds S.
A graph is a gc_605 if it can be generated from the empty graph by the operation: G' = (G \cup pK_1) \times K_{r,r} \times K_q, with p+q+r > 0.

GraphClass.name: totally unimodular
GraphClass.note:
A matrix is totally unimodular if the determinant of every induced square submatrix is equal to -1,0, or +1
A graph is gc_606 if its clique matrix is totally unimodular.

GraphClass.name: split-neighbourhood
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_608 if every induced subgraph has a vertex whose neighbourhood induces a gc_39 graph.

GraphClass.name: pretty
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_609 if every induced subgraph has a vertex whose neighbourhood is gc_171.

GraphClass.name: p-tree
GraphClass.note:
G is a p-cycle if every vertex of G is contained in at least two P_4s and every proper induced subgraph of G has a vertex occuring in at most 1 P_4.
A graph is a gc_611 if it is gc_348 and contains no p-cycle.
Forbidden subgraphs for gc_108.
Forbidden subgraphs for gc_35.

GraphClass.name: nearly bipartite
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_640 if for every node v, G-N[v] is gc_69.

The following different classes are sometimes also called gc_640:
Graphs that can be made gc_69 by deleting one vertex.
Graphs that can be made gc_69 by deleting at most k nodes, for fixed k.

GraphClass.name: concave-round
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_641 if its vertices can be circularly enumerated such that the closed neighbourhood of every vertex is an interval in the enumeration.

GraphClass.name: convex-round
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_642 if its vertices can be circularly enumerated such that the open neighbourhood of every vertex is an interval in the enumeration.

GraphClass.name: circular convex bipartite
GraphClass.note: A gc_69 graph (X,Y,E) is gc_644 if X can be circularly ordered such that for every vertex in Y, its neighbourhood is an interval of the ordering.

GraphClass.name: interval enumerable
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_646 if its vertices can be linearly ordered such that for every vertex its lower numbered neighbours form an interval in the ordering.

GraphClass.name: k-leaf power, fixed $k$
GraphClass.note: A graph G is a gc_649 if there is a tree T whose leaves correspond to the vertices of G in such a way that two vertices are adjacent in G precisely when their distance in T is at most k.

algo.name: Cliquewidth
algo.note: Bounded by 3k/2

GraphClass.name: 4-leaf power
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_650 it it results from replacing every vertex of a gc_770 by a clique of arbitrary size.

GraphClass.name: 3-leaf power
GraphClass.note: A connected graph is a gc_651 iff it results from at tree by replacing every vertex by a clique of arbitrary size.

GraphClass.name: (1,2)-polar
GraphClass.note:
