A gc_665 graph is a graph G whose vertex set can be partitioned into two sets A and B, such that the connected components of co-G[A] and G[B] are complete graphs of size at most 1, 2, respectively.
Note that this means that G[A] is a clique.

GraphClass.name: perfect connected-dominant
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_668 if for every induced subgraph H, the size of a minimum dominating set and the size of a connected minimum dominating set are equal.
This class is defined by some forbidden subgraphs for gc_472 graphs.

algo.name: Independent set
algo.note: gc_675 are precisely the gc_472 graphs of gc_43 graphs.

algo.name: Cutwidth
algo.note: From ref_1648 and ref_1509.

GraphClass.name: charming
GraphClass.note:
A vertex v of a graph G is called charming iff it is not the endpoint of a P_5 in G, not the endpoint of a P_5 in the complement of G and does not lie on a C_5 of G.
A graph is gc_676 if every induced subgraph has a charming vertex.
Every graph in this graphclass is either a clique or possesses two non-adjacent charming vertices.

GraphClass.name: slim
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_680 if it can be obtained from a gc_194 graph by deleting all edges between an arbitrary set of nodes.
gc_681 were introduced as gc_680 graphs.

GraphClass.name: 1-bounded bipartite
GraphClass.note: A gc_69 graph (X,Y,E) is gc_685 if every vertex in X, resp. Y, has at most 1 non-neighbour in Y, resp. X.

GraphClass.name: 2-bounded bipartite
GraphClass.note: A gc_69 graph (X,Y,E) is gc_687 if every every vertex in X, resp. Y, has at most 2 non-neighbour in Y, resp. X.

GraphClass.name: 1-bounded tripartite
GraphClass.note: A gc_453 graph is gc_689 if every vertex in partite set Xi has at most 1 non-neighbour in every partite set Xj, i unequal to j.

GraphClass.name: upper irredundance perfect
GraphClass.note:
A vertex x is said to be redundant in a vertex set X if N[x] - N[X\x] is empty. A set that contains no redundant vertices is irredundant. The upper irredundance number IR(G) of G is the maximum cardinality taken over all irredundant vertex sets of G.
The maximum cardinality of a minimum dominating set of G is called the upper domination number \Gamma(G).
A graph is gc_690 if for every induced subgraph H: IR(H) = \Gamma(H).

GraphClass.name: upper domination perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_691 if for every induced subgraph the maximum cardinality of a minimal dominating set equals the maximum cardinality of an independent set.

GraphClass.name: strong domination perfect
GraphClass.note:
A set X is called a strong dominating set of G=(V,E), if every every vertex u in V-X is adjacent to a vertex v in X such that d(v)>=d(u), where d(x) is the degree of vertex x.
An independent strong dominating set of G is a strong dominating set that is independent.
A graph is gc_694 if for every induced subgraph the size of a minimal strong dominating set equals the size of a minimal independent strong dominating set.
For every induced subgraph the size of a minimal strong dominating set equals the size of a minimal dominating set.
For every induced subgraph the size of a minimal independent strong dominating set equals the size of a minimal dominating set.
For every induced subgraph the size of a minimal independent strong dominating set equals the size of a minimal independent dominating set.

GraphClass.name: clique-perfect
GraphClass.note:
A clique-transversal of a graph G is a set of vertices intersecting all the maximal cliques of G. A clique-independent set of G is a set of pairwise disjoint maximal cliques of G.
A graph is gc_699 if for every induced subgraph the size of a minimum clique-transversal equals the size of a maximum clique-independent set.

GraphClass.name: slender
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_702 if it can be obtained from a gc_191 graph G by deleting all edges of a matching M in G.

GraphClass.name: skeletal
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_703 if it can be obtained from a gc_75 graph G by selecting a set of vertices N in G such that the vertices in N have pairwise distance at least 3 and deleting an arbitrary set of edges of G that all have one endpoint in N.

GraphClass.name: quasi-Meyniel
GraphClass.note: A building is a cycle with at least five vertices, with a single chord the forms a triangle with two edges of a cycle (i.e. a single chord that is a short chord). A graph is gc_704 if it is gc_356 and it has a vertex x that is the endvertex of the chord of every building.
Confusion danger: This class is sometimes called gc_547.

GraphClass.name: line graphs of multigraphs without triangles
line graphs of bipartite multigraphs
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_712 iff its gc_141 graph is gc_69.

GraphClass.name: line graphs of Helly hypergraphs of rank 3
GraphClass.note: The rank of a hypergraph is the maximum size of its hyperedges.

GraphClass.name: 3-mino
GraphClass.note: G is a gc_715 graph if every vertex of G is contained in at most three maximal cliques of G.

GraphClass.name: line graphs of linear hypergraphs of rank 3
GraphClass.note:
The rank of a hypergraphs is the maximum size of its hyperedges.
A hypergraph is linear if every pair of edges has at most 1 common vertex.

GraphClass.name: maximum degree 4
GraphClass.note: A graph is of gc_717 when no vertex has more than 4 neighbours.
A graph is of gc_717 if it is XC_{11}-free.
Is every graph of gc_717 an gc_1158?

GraphClass.name: linear domino
GraphClass.note: A gc_179 is called linear if every edge belongs to exactly one maximal clique.

GraphClass.name: maximum degree 3
GraphClass.note: A graph is of gc_720 when no vertex has more than 3 neighbours.
A graph is of gc_720 if it is XC_{12}-free.

GraphClass.name: 2-tree
GraphClass.note: See gc_594.

GraphClass.name: maximal outerplanar
GraphClass.note: An gc_110 graph is gc_723 if it is not possible to add an edge such that the resulting graph is still gc_110.

GraphClass.name: rectangle visibility
GraphClass.note:
Let R be a collection of rectangles in the plane, such that each rectangle has its sides parallel to the axes. Rectangles may share boundary points, but not interior points. We say that two rectangles u, v are visible to each other if there is an axis-parallel rectangle (of non-zero width), called band of visibility, with opposite sides that are subsets of u and v and that intersects no other rectangle of R.
The visibility graph of R is the graph of the visibility relation of the elements of R.
A graph is a gc_724 if it is the visibility graph of some collection of rectangles.
gc_725 are sometimes also called gc_724.

GraphClass.name: weak rectangle visibility
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_725 graph if it can be drawn in the plane such that vertices are represented by rectangles that are aligned with the axes and edges are horizontal or vertical lines of sight (note that not every line of sight need to be an edge).

GraphClass.name: partial rectangle visibility
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_726 graph if it is a (not necessarily induced) subgraph of a gc_724.

GraphClass.name: bar visibility
GraphClass.note:
Let B be a collection of closed horizontal line segments in the plane, pairwise disjoint except for possibly shared endpoints. We say that two segments u, v are visible to each other if there is a vertical rectangle (of non-zero width), called band of visibility, with opposite sides that are subsets of u and v and that intersects no other segment of B.
The visibility graph of B is the graph of the visibility relation of the elements of B.
A graph is a gc_727 if it is the visibility graph of some collection of horizontal line segments.

GraphClass.name: thickness \le 2
GraphClass.note:
A graph is of thickness k if it can be decomposed into k gc_43 graphs, but not into k-1 gc_43 graphs.
A graph is of gc_728 if it either is gc_43 or is the union of 2 gc_43 graphs.

GraphClass.name: biplanar
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_729 if it is the union of 2 gc_43 graphs.
gc_729 is also used for graphs that have thickness precisely 2, instead of thickness at most 2 (see gc_728 for a definition of thickness).

GraphClass.name: weak bar visibility
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_730 graph if it can be drawn in the plane such that vertices are represented by horizontal line segments and edges are vertical lines of sight of non-zero width (note that not every line of sight need be an edge).

GraphClass.name: partial bar visibility
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_731 graph if it is a (not necessarily induced) subgraph of a gc_727 graph.

GraphClass.name: caterpillar arboricity \le 2
GraphClass.note: A graph has gc_732 if it can be decomposed into (is the union of) at most 2 forests whose connected components are gc_784.

GraphClass.name: linear arboricity \le 2
GraphClass.note: A graph has gc_733 if it can be decomposed into (is the union of) at most 2 forests whose connected components are linear forests (=paths).

GraphClass.name: partial 4--tree
GraphClass.note: See gc_595

GraphClass.name: gridline
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_736 graph if it can be drawn in the plane with vertices adjacent whenever they are on a common vertical or horizontal line.
A graph is a gc_736 graph if it is gc_441 and its gc_141 graph is gc_69.

GraphClass.name: frame hereditary dominating pair
GraphClass.note:
Three vertices of a graph form an asteroidal triple if every two of them are connected by a path avoiding the neighbourhood of the third.
A graph G is gc_738 (frame HDP) if it is a gc_567 graph with an asteroidal triple T such that all vertices of G are on an induced path between two vertices of T that avoid the neighbourhood of the third vertex of T.

GraphClass.name: grid intersection
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_739 graph iff it is the intersection graph of horizontal and vertical line segments in the plane.

GraphClass.name: string
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_741 graph if it is the intersection graph of curves in the plane.
A graph is gc_747 iff every triangle contains an edge such that any common neighbour of the vertices of the edge is also adjacent to the third vertex of the triangle.

A set S of sets Si has the strong Helly property if the cardinality of the intersection of all Si equals the cardinality of the intersection of Si and Sj, for all i!=j.
A graph is gc_747 iff its clique hypergraph has the strong Helly property.
A graph is gc_748 iff it does contain XZ_{15} as an induced subgraph.

GraphClass.name: maximal clique irreducible
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_749 if every maximal clique in G contains an edge that is not contained in any other maximal clique.

GraphClass.name: unit bar visibility
GraphClass.note: A gc_727 graph is a gc_751 if it has a visibility representation with all bars of unit length.

GraphClass.name: circular perfect
GraphClass.note:
For 1<=d<=k, let Kk/d be the graph with vertices 0,1...k-1 and edges ij iff d<=|i-j|<=k-d. For example, an odd-hole C2n+1 equals K(2n+1)/n and the co-cycle co-Cn equals Kn/2.
A homomorphism from a graph G to a graph H is a mapping f:V(G)->V(H) such that f(x)f(y) \in E(H) whenever xy\in E(G).
The circular chromatic number \chi_c(G) of a graph G is the minimal k/d such that a homomorphism from G to Kk/d exists. In other words, \chi_c(G) is the minimal k/d for which a function f: V(G) -> {0,..,k-1} exist such that for adjacent vertices x,y: d<=|f(x)-f(y)|<=k-d.
The circular clique number \omega_c(G) of a graph G is the maximal k/d such that a homomorphism from Kk/d to G exists.
A graph is gc_753 if for every induced subgraph H, \chi_c(H) = \omega_c(H).

GraphClass.name: biclique separable
GraphClass.note: A biclique cutset is a cutset that induces the disjoint union of two cliques (so a biclique cutset induces the complement of a biclique!). A graph is gc_754 if it is gc_437 and each induced subgraph that is not a clique contains a clique cutset or a biclique cutset.
A graph is gc_764 it its vertex set can be partitioned into three, possibly empty, sets C, S, I, such that C is a clique, S, I are independent sets and there is a join between C and S.

GraphClass.name: square of tree
GraphClass.note: Given a graph G=(V,E), Gk=(V,E') has an edge (u,v) iff dG(u,v) <= k.

G is a gc_770 iff it is gc_32, gc_771 and its maximal cliques have the following properties:
Every two distinct maximal cliques have at most two vertices in common.
Every 2-cut belongs to exactly two maximal cliques.
Every pair of non-disjoint 2-cuts belongs to the same maximal clique.
All 2-cuts contained in the same maximal clique of G have a common vertex.

GraphClass.name: 2-connected
GraphClass.note: A graph is k-connected if it cannot be disconnected by removing less than k vertices.

GraphClass.name: basic 4-leaf power
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_775 if it is a gc_650 such that to every internal vertex of the corresponding tree only one leaf is attached.
A graph is a gc_775 if it is an induced subgraph of a gc_770.
A graph is a gc_775 if every block is a gc_770, and for every non-disjoint pair of block, at least one of them is a clique.

GraphClass.name: cycle-bicolorable
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_777 if its vertices can be coloured with 2 colours such that the colours alternate on every induced cycle of length at least 4.

GraphClass.name: alternately colourable
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_778 if its edges can be coloured with 2 colours such that the colours alternate on every induced cycle of length at least 4.

GraphClass.name: Bouchet
GraphClass.note: Let the local complement G*v result from G by complementing G[N(v)]. Two graphs are said to be locally equivalent if one results from the other by a series of local complements. Note that this is an equivalence relation. A graph G is a gc_780 graph iff no induced subgraph of G is locally equivalent to W_5,BW_3 or W_7.

GraphClass.name: quasi-threshold
GraphClass.note:
gc_781 graphs are defined recursively as follows:
K_1 is a gc_781 graph
Adding a new vertex adjacent to all vertices of a gc_781 graph results in a gc_781 graph
The disjoint union of two gc_781 graphs results in a gc_781 graph.

GraphClass.name: graceful
GraphClass.note:
Let G be a graph with e edges. A numbering f of the vertices of G with distinct numbers from 0..e is called graceful if, when edges (x,y) are labelled with |f(x)-f(y)|, different edges have different labels.
A graph is gc_783 if it has a graceful numbering.
*** gc_342s are gc_783. (Ringel-Kotzig, see ref_1329).

GraphClass.name: caterpillar
GraphClass.note: A caterpillar is a gc_342 that has a dominating path.

GraphClass.name: harmonious
GraphClass.note:
Let G be a graph with e edges. A numbering f of the vertices of G with distinct numbers from 0..e-1 is called harmonious if, when edges (x,y) are labelled with f(x)+f(y) (mod e), different edges have different labels.
A graph is gc_785 if it has a harmonious numbering.

A collection of sets U is consecutively orderable if the sets can be indexed U1,..,Un, such that for all i <= j <= k, whenever x is in Ui and in Uk, then x is in Uj.
Let G be a gc_69 graph with vertex partition (U,N), not necessarily a bipartition, where G(N) is an independent set. A U-star is either a star with a vertex of maximum degree in U and pendants in N, or a K_2 with both vertices in U.
A gc_69 graph G is in gc_790 if there exists a vertex partition (U,N) with G(N) independent such that the edges of G can be partitioned into consecutively orderable U-stars.

GraphClass.name: disk-Helly
GraphClass.note: A synonym for gc_105.
This class is characterised by forbidding subgraphs for gc_761

GraphClass.name: subtree filament
GraphClass.note:
A graph is a gc_810 graph if it has an intersection model of the following form:
Let T be a tree in a plane P and let t1,...tn be subtree of T.Subtree filaments on the subtree ti are constructed in a surface perpendicular to P whose intersection with P is exactly T. In this surface, in and above T, we construct filaments f1,...,fn where each fi is a curve connecting the leaves of ti such that (i) filaments corresponding to disjoint subtrees do not intersect, and (ii) filaments corresponding to overlapping subtrees intersect. Filaments corresponding to subtrees on of which is contained in the other may or may not intersect.
This is the largest probe class that is a subclass of gc_14 ref_1354.

GraphClass.name: 5-leaf power
GraphClass.note: A graph G is a gc_825 if there is a tree T whose leaves correspond to the vertices of G in such a way that two vertices are adjacent in G precisely when their distance in T is at most 5.
Give a structural characterisation of gc_825s ref_1356.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: Polynomial if a probe partition is given ref_1359.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: Polynomial if a probe partition is given ref_1359.

GraphClass.name: CIS
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_832 if each maximal clique intersects each maximal stable (= independent) set.

GraphClass.name: almost CIS
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_833 if it has a unique disjoint pair (C,S) consisting of a maximal clique C and a maximal independent set S.
A graph is gc_833 if it is a gc_39 graph with a unique split partition.
When a gc_39 graph does not have a unique split partition, then it is a gc_832 (but not vice versa).

GraphClass.name: module-composed
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_834 if its vertices can be ordered v1...vn, such that the neighbourhood of vi is a module of the graph induced by v1...vi-1. The ordering v1...vn is called the module sequence of the graph.

GraphClass.name: independent module-composed
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_835 if its vertices can be ordered v1...vn, such that the neighbourhood of vi is both an independent set in G and a module of the graph induced by v1...vi-1. The ordering v1...vn is called the independent module sequence of the graph.

An edge ab of G is a symmetric wing if there exist vertices c,d,p,q such that both abcd and bapq are P_4s in G.
A graph is gc_845 iff it contains no symmetric wing.

GraphClass.name: binary tree
GraphClass.note: A gc_342 is a gc_847 if every vertex has degree at most 3. If a root is appointed in the tree, then every vertex has at most 2 children, hence the name binary.

GraphClass.name: 3d grid
GraphClass.note: An $k\times n\times m$ gc_849 is the cartesian product of three paths $P_k$, $P_n$ and $P_m$.

GraphClass.name: partial 3d grid
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_850 iff it is an arbitrary subgraph (not necessarily induced) of a gc_849.

GraphClass.name: semicircular
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_851 if it has an intersection model consisting of open semicircles on a circle. In other words, it is a gc_133 graph that has a circular arc model in which every arc is open and spans 180 degrees of the circle.

GraphClass.name: normal circular arc
GraphClass.note: A gc_133 graph is a gc_861 graph if it admits a circular arc model such that no two arcs cover the circle.
Characterize gc_861 graphs and give a recognition algorithm.

GraphClass.name: SEG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_862 graph if it is the intersection graph of straight line segments in the plane.

GraphClass.name: k-DIR
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_863 graph if it is the intersection graph of straight line segments lying in at most k directions in the plane.

GraphClass.name: 2-DIR
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_864 graph if it is the intersection graph of straight line segments lying in at most 2 directions in the plane.

GraphClass.name: 1-DIR
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_865 graph if it is the intersection graph of straight line segments lying in at most 1 direction in the plane.

GraphClass.name: PURE-k-DIR
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_866 graph if it is the intersection graph of straight line segments lying in at most k directions in the plane, with the additional condition that any two parallel segments are disjoint.

GraphClass.name: PURE-2-DIR
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_867 graph if it is the intersection graph of straight line segments lying in at most 2 directions in the plane, with the additional condition that any two parallel segments are disjoint.

GraphClass.name: PURE-3-DIR
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_868 graph if it is the intersection graph of straight line segments lying in at most 3 directions in the plane, with the additional condition that any two parallel segments are disjoint.

GraphClass.name: 1-string
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_870 graph if it is the intersection graph of strings in the plane, such that any two strings intersect at most once.
The neighbourhood of every vertex is gc_171.

GraphClass.name: semiperfectly orderable
GraphClass.note:
A vertex is semisimplicial in G if it is midpoint of no P_4 in G.
A vertex ordering v1...vn is a semiperfect elimination ordering of G if vi is semisimplicial in the graph induced by v1...vi.
A graph is gc_872 if it has a semiperfect elimination order.

GraphClass.name: 2-terminal series--parallel
GraphClass.note:
A two-terminal labelled graph (G,s,t) consist of a graph G with a marked source s and sink t.
The series composition of two-terminal labelled graphs (G,s,t) and (H,x,y) with t=x is (G\cup H, s, y).
The parallel composition of (G,s,t) and (H,x,y) with s=x and t=y is (G\cup H, s, t).
A graph is a gc_875 if it can be created from single two-terminal labelled edges by series and/or parallel compositions.

GraphClass.name: balanced 2-interval
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_876 grraph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consist of 2 equal length intervals on a real line.

GraphClass.name: unit 2-interval
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_877 iff it has an intersection model whose objects consist of 2 intervals of length 1 on a real line.

A graph is an (x,x)-interval graph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consist of 2 open intervals of length x with integer endpoints on a real line.
A graph is a gc_877 iff it is an (x,x)-interval graphs for some x.

GraphClass.name: (2,2)-interval
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_878 graph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consist of 2 open intervals of length 2 with integer endpoints on a real line.
Note that without the condition of integer endpoints this class would simply be equal to gc_877.

GraphClass.name: quasi-line
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_879 graph iff the closed neighbourhood of every vertex is the union of two cliques.

GraphClass.name: all-4-simplicial
GraphClass.note: A graph is an gc_880 graph iff the closed neighbourhood of every vertex is the union of at most 4 cliques.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: Recognition of all-k-simplicial graphs is NP-Complete for all k >= 3 ref_1400.

GraphClass.name: proper interval bigraph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_882 if it is an gc_167 with an intersection model such that no two intervals in the same bipartite set overlap.

GraphClass.name: unit interval bigraph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_882 if it is an gc_167 with an intersection model such that all intervals have unit length.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: with $\Delta$ the maximum degree of the graph, assuming the intersection model is given ref_1647

GraphClass.name: proper Helly circular arc
GraphClass.note:
A graph is gc_889 if it has a circular arc model that is both proper and Helly.
Note that is stronger than requiring that the graph is both a gc_297 and a gc_205 graph.
A graph is gc_889 if it admits a proper circular arc model in which no two nor three arcs cover the circle. ref_1651.

A graph is gc_889 if it admits a proper circular arc model in which no three arcs cover the circle. ref_1659. Note that in any model on at least 3 arcs in which two arcs cover the circle, there are also three arcs that together cover the circle.

GraphClass.name: interval containment bigraph
GraphClass.note: A gc_69 graph $B=(X,Y,E)$ is an gc_891 if every vertex can be assigned an interval on the real line such that for all $x \in X$ and $y \in Y$: $xy \in E$ iff the interval assigned to $x$ contains the interval assigned to $y$.

GraphClass.name: strongly circular perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_895 iff both G and its complement are gc_753.

algo.name: Weighted clique
algo.note: No clique can have more than 4 vertices

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of posets of interval dimension d
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_904 if it is the gc_72 of a poset of interval dimension d.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: For d >= 3 ref_1093

GraphClass.name: d-trapezoid
GraphClass.note:
Let L1...Ld be d parallel lines in the plane. A d-trapezoid is the polygon obtained by choosing an interval Ii on every line Li and connecting the left, resp. right endpoint of Ii with the left, resp. right endpoint of Ii+1.
A graph is a gc_906 graph if it has an intersection model consisting of d-trapezoids between d parallel lines.

algo.name: Treewidth
algo.note: Assuming an intersection model is given ref_1417.

algo.name: Clique cover
algo.note: Assuming an intersection model is given ref_1120.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Assume an intersection model is given ref_1120.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of dimension d posets
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_907 if it is the gc_72 of a poset of dimension d. (The dimension of a poset P is the minimal number of linear extensions of P whose intersection is P.)

GraphClass.name: planar of maximum degree 4
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_909 if it is gc_43 and every vertex has degree at most 4.

GraphClass.name: overlap
GraphClass.note: A graph is an gc_913 if its vertices may be put into a one-to-one correspondence with intervals on a line, such that two vertices are adjacent iff there intervals partially overlap, that is, they have non-empty intersection, but neither contains the other.

algo.name: Colourability
algo.note: The chromatic number is at most 5.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: Finite forbidden subgraph characterization.

GraphClass.note: These are precisely the gc_371 graphs that are of gc_717.

GraphClass.name: locally connected
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_932 iff for every vertex v, the open neighbourhood N(v) of v induces a connected graph in G.

GraphClass.name: path orderable
GraphClass.note:
A vertex v in a graph G intercepts a path if v is adjacent to at least one vertex of the path and it misses the path otherwise
An ordering v1..vn of the vertices of G such that for each triple v, w, x with v < w < x in the ordering w intercepts each path from v to x, is called a path ordering.
A graph G is gc_933 if it admits a path ordering.

GraphClass.name: strong asteroid free
GraphClass.note:
For a graph G and a vertex v of G, let C1...Ck be the connected components of G\N[v]. Let Bi1,...Bil be the connected components of the graph induced by the vertices of Ci in co-G. The Bij are called the blobs of v in G.
An odd strong asteroid of size k in a graph G is a sequence of vertices v0...vk, where k is odd, v1..vk are distinct, v0 = vk and for all i, 0 <= i < k, vi and vi+1 are in the same blob of vi+(k+1)/2 (addition modulo k).
A graph G is gc_934 if it does not contain an odd strong asteroid.

GraphClass.name: 3-DIR
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_935 graph if it is the intersection graph of straight line segments lying in at most 3 directions in the plane.

GraphClass.name: 3-DIR contact
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_936 graph if it is a gc_935 graph with the additional condition that no two segments cross (i.e. have no interior point in common).

GraphClass.name: strongly 3-colorable
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_937 if its vertex set can be partitioned into 3 independent sets C1, C2, C3, such that for every vertex v there is an i such v is adjacent to all vertices in Ci.

GraphClass.name: k-starlike
GraphClass.note: Let G be a gc_32 graph such that its clique tree T is a star. Let X0,...Xn be the maximal cliques of G, with X0 corresponding to the center of T. A graph is gc_944 if max |Xi\ X0| = k.
Graphs that have a spanning tree homeomorphic to a star are sometimes also called starlike. Such graphs are incomparable to gc_944 graphs.

GraphClass.name: triangulated
GraphClass.note: Synonym for gc_32.

GraphClass.name: self-clique
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_946 if it is isomorphic to its gc_141 graph.
A graph is in gc_947 if it is both gc_946 and gc_205.

Given a graph G and k>=0, the graph Gk has the same vertices as G, two vertices being adjacent in Gk if their distance in G is at most k.
A graph is in gc_947 if it is isomorphic to C_nk for some k>=0 such that 3k<n.
A graph is in gc_948 if it is both gc_946 and gc_747.

A vertex-clique duality is a bijection f which maps vertices to cliques and cliques to vertices in such a way that for a vertex v and a clique C, v\in C iff f(C) \in f(v).
A graph is in gc_947 if it admits a vertex-clique duality.

Let G be a graph with vertices v1,..,vn and cliques C1,..,Cm. The (0,1) matrix A = (aij) where aij is 1 iff vertex vi belongs to clique Cj is called a clique matrix of G.
A matrix is quasi-symmetric if its families of row and column vectors are identical.
A graph is in gc_947 iff it has a quasi-symmetric clique matrix.

GraphClass.name: co--interval mixed
outer-string
GraphClass.note: A graph is an gc_951 graph if it has an intersection model consisting of curves lying in a disk, with one endpoint on the boundary of the disk.

GraphClass.name: CONV
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_952 graph if it has an intersection model consisting of convex sets in the plane.

GraphClass.name: disk contact
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_954 graph if it is a gc_414 graph with the additional condition that no two disks have more than one point in common.

GraphClass.name: coin
GraphClass.note: Alias for gc_954

GraphClass.name: triangle contact
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_956 graph if it has an intersection model consisting of triangles in a plane such that no two triangles have more than one point in common.

GraphClass.name: balanced
GraphClass.note:
Let G be a graph with vertices v1,..,vn and cliques C1,..,Cm. The (0,1) matrix A = (aij) where aij is 1 iff vertex vi belongs to clique Cj is called a clique matrix of G.
A (0,1)-matrix is balanced if it does not contain the vertex-edge incidence matrix of an odd-cycle as a submatrix (that is, it contains no square submatrix of odd order with exactly two 1s per row and per column.)
A graph is gc_957 if its clique matrix is balanced.
A graph is in gc_963 if it is both gc_957 and gc_357.
A graph G is gc_963 if every connected component of G is either gc_69 or is the join of a complete bipartite graph and a complete graph.
A graph is in gc_966 if it is both gc_957 and a gc_249 graph.

A graph G is gc_966 if it is the gc_249 graph of a graph R such that:
If U is the set of vertices of R of degree 2 whose two neighbours are adjacent
and E' is het set of edges of R whose both endpoints are the neighbours of one vertex in U,
then R-U is gc_69 and every edge of R-U that is a member of E' belongs to no cycle of R-U.
A graph is in gc_971 if it is both gc_957 and gc_970.
A graph G is gc_971 if the clique matrix (see gc_957 of G has no square submatrix of order 3, 5, or 7 with exactly two 1s per row and per column.

GraphClass.name: unit Helly circular arc
GraphClass.note:
A graph is gc_974 if it has a circular arc model that is both a unit model and Helly.
Note that is stronger than requiring that the graph is both a gc_304 and a gc_205 graph.
A graph is gc_974 if it admits a unit circular arc model in which no two nor three arcs cover the circle. ref_1651.

A graph is gc_974 if it admits a unit circular arc model in which no three arcs cover the circle. ref_1659. Note that in any model on at least 3 arcs in which two arcs cover the circle, there are also three arcs that together cover the circle.

GraphClass.name: 2-thin
GraphClass.note: A graph G=(V,E) is k-thin if there exist an ordering < of the vertices of G and a partition of V into k sets, with the property that, for each triple of vertices r, s, t with r<s<t: if r and s are in the same partitioned set and tr is an edge, then ts is an edge.

The gc_234 graphs are precisely the 1-thin graphs.
The thinness of a graph G is the minimum k such that G is k-thin.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Assuming a k-partition is given ref_1463.

GraphClass.name: perfectly colorable
GraphClass.note:
Let \omega(G) be the size of a maximum clique in G.
A perfect coloring of a graph G is a proper coloring of G such that every connected induced subgraph H of G uses exactly \omega(H) many colors.
A graph is gc_979 if it admits a perfect coloring.

GraphClass.name: Apollonian network
GraphClass.note:
gc_980s are defined recursively as follows:
The triangle is an gc_980.
If G is an gc_980, then the graph obtained by embedding G in the plane, selecting a triangular face F of the embedding, adding a new vertex v inside the face and connecting v to each vertex of F, is again an gc_980.
Note that the definition given here differs slightly from that in ref_1469 where all faces are subdivided equally often.

GraphClass.name: maximal planar
GraphClass.note: A gc_43 graph is gc_981 if it is not possible to add an edge such that the graph is still gc_43.

GraphClass.name: 3-tree
GraphClass.note: See gc_594.

GraphClass.name: polyhedral
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_986 if it is the graph formed by the vertices and edges of convex polyhedron.

A graph is k-vertex-connected if you need to delete at least k vertices before the resulting graph is disconnected.
A graph is gc_986 if it is 3-vertex-connected and gc_43 (a.k.a. Steinitz' Theorem).

GraphClass.name: $\beta$-perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_987 if for all induced subgraphs H: \chi(H) = \beta(H), where \chi(H) is the chromatic number of H and \beta(H) is the maximum of the minimum degree of the induced subgraphs of H, plus 1.

GraphClass.name: even-signable
GraphClass.note:
A signing of a graph G assigns every edge of G a label from {0,1}.
Let G be a signed graph. A set of edges is called even if the sum of its labels is even and odd if the sum of its edges is odd.
G is gc_992 if it can be signed such that every triangle is odd and every induced cycle on at least four vertices even.

GraphClass.name: odd-signable
GraphClass.note:
A signing of a graph G assigns every edge of G a label from {0,1}.
Let G be a signed graph. A set of edges is called even if the sum of its labels is even and odd if the sum of its edges is odd.
G is gc_993 if it can be signed such that every triangle is odd and every induced cycle on at least four vertices odd.

GraphClass.name: strongly even-signable
GraphClass.note:
A signing of a graph G assigns every edge of G a label from {0,1}.
Let G be a signed graph. A set of edges is called even if the sum of its labels is even and odd if the sum of its edges is odd.
G is gc_994 if it can be signed such that every triangle is odd and every induced cycle with at most 1 chord on at least four vertices even.

GraphClass.name: strongly odd-signable
GraphClass.note:
A signing of a graph G assigns every edge of G a label from {0,1}.
Let G be a signed graph. A set of edges is called even if the sum of its labels is even and odd if the sum of its edges is odd.
G is gc_995 if it can be signed such that every diamond is even and every induced cycle odd.

GraphClass.name: b-perfect
GraphClass.note:
A b-colouring of a graph G is a colouring of the vertices of G such that each colour class contains a vertex that has a neighbour in every other colour class.
The b-chromatic number of a graph G is the largest integer k such that G admits a b-colouring with k colours.
A graph G is gc_1003 if for every induced subgraph of G, the b-choromatic number is equal to the chromatic number.

GraphClass.name: homothetic triangle contact
GraphClass.note:
Two triangles are homothetic if they only differ in geometric contraction or expansion.
A graph is a gc_1005 graph if it has an intersection model consisting of homothetic triangles in a plane such that no two triangles have more than one point in common.

GraphClass.name: max-tolerance
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1007 graph if every vertex v can be assigned a closed interval Iv on the real line and a tolerance tv such that x and y are adjacent iff |Ix \cap Iy| >= max{tx, ty}.

algo.name: Weighted clique
algo.note: There are O(V3) maximal cliques in a max-tolerance graph.

GraphClass.name: semi-square intersection
GraphClass.note:
A semi-square is an axis-parallel isosceles triangle (i.e. the lower half of a diagonally cut axis-parallel square).
A graph is a gc_1008 graph if every vertex can be assigned a semi-square such that two vertices are adjacent iff their semi-squares intersect.

A collection of sets U is consecutively orderable if the sets can be indexed U1,..,Un, such that for all i <= j <= k, whenever x is in Ui and in Uk, then x is in Uj.
A gc_69 graph G=(V,E) is in gc_1009 if there exist a consecutively orderable partition of E into stars.

GraphClass.name: biclique--Helly
GraphClass.note:
The biclique hypergraph of G has V(G) as its vertices and the induced maximal complete bipartite subgraphs (bicliques) of G as its hyperedges.
A graph is gc_1015 iff its biclique hypergraph has the Helly property.

GraphClass.name: Helly circle
GraphClass.note: A gc_132 graph is a gc_1017 graph iff it has an intersection model that has the Helly property.

GraphClass.name: unit Helly circle
GraphClass.note: A gc_132 graph is a gc_1019 graph iff it has an intersection model such that all chords in the model are the same size and the model has the Helly property.
A graph is a gc_1019 graph iff it is a chordless cycle, a complete graph or a disjoint union of chordless paths.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: where $a$ is the arboricity of the graph ref_1645.

GraphClass.name: SC $k$-tree, fixed $k$
GraphClass.note:
A complete graph on k nodes is a gc_1027 (short for simple-clique k-tree).
If G is a gc_1027 and C is a k-clique of G not previously chosen in the construction of G, then the graph formed by adding a new vertex to G, and making it adjacent to all nodes of C is a gc_1027.

GraphClass.name: SC 2-tree
GraphClass.note: See gc_1027.

GraphClass.name: SC 3-tree
GraphClass.note: See gc_1027.

GraphClass.name: $k$-path graph, fixed $k$
GraphClass.note:
A k-path of G is an alternating sequence of distinct k- and k+1-cliques of G, [e0, t1, e1,..., tp, ep], starting and ending with a k-clique and such that ti contains exactly two k-cliques, ei-1 and ei.
Let G be a gc_594 with more than k vertices. If there is a k-path P in G, such that G and the graph induced by the vertices of the k+1-cliques ti of P are isomorphic, then G is a gc_1030.
Let G be a gc_594 with more than k vertices. G is a gc_1030 iff G has exactly two simplicial vertices.
A particular type of intersection graph of paths of length k in a graph are sometimes also called k-path graphs, see ref_1492.

GraphClass.name: double-split
GraphClass.note:
A graph G=(V,E) is gc_1033 if its vertex set can be partitioned into two sets A and B, such that the followings hold:
G[A] is a disjoint union of edges
G[B] is the complement of a disjoint union of edges
for all adjacent u, v in A and all x in B, x is adjacent to exactly one of u and v
for all u in A and all non-adjacent x, y in B, u is adjacent to exactly one of x and y

The proof of the strong perfect graph theorem in ref_1128 uses a decomposition theorem, stating that all gc_56 graphs either belong to the gc_69, gc_486, gc_251, gc_744 or the gc_1033 graph or admit one of several decompositions.

GraphClass.name: doubled
GraphClass.note: A graph G is a gc_1034 graph if there is a gc_1033 graph H that contains G as an induced subgraph.

GraphClass.name: almost-split
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_1036 if G is gc_1034 and it contains a vertex v such that G-v is gc_39.

GraphClass.name: bitolerance
GraphClass.note: Another name for gc_272 graphs.

GraphClass.name: normal Helly circular arc
GraphClass.note:
A graph is gc_1040 if it has a circular arc model that is both normal and Helly.
Note that is stronger than requiring that the graph is both a gc_861 and a gc_205 graph.

A dismantling of a graph G is the subgraph of G obtained by iteratively removing a vertex which is dominated by some other vertex in the subgraph obtained so far (see also gc_49). A graph is gc_1040 iff it is either gc_234 or its dismantling is gc_947.
A graph is gc_1040 if it admits a circular arc model in which no two nor three arcs cover the circle. ref_1651

A graph is gc_1040 if it admits a circular arc model in which no three arcs cover the circle. ref_1659. Note that in any model on at least 3 arcs in which two arcs cover the circle, there are also three arcs that together cover the circle.

GraphClass.name: parallelepiped
GraphClass.note:
Let L and M be two parallel lines in 3-dimensional Euclidean space. Without loss of generality assume L={(.,0,0)} and M={(.,1,0)}.
A special parallelepiped on L and M is either
the convex hull of eight points
A = (a,1,0)A' = (a,1,z)
B = (b,0,0)B' = (b,0,z)
C = (c,0,0)C' = (c,0,z)
D = (d,1,0)D' = (d,1,z)
for some a,b,c,d,z >= 0 with ADBC a parallelogram between L and M; or
the line segment between (a,1,z) and (b,0,z) for some a,b,z >= 0.
A graph is a gc_1041 graph if it is the intersection graph of special parallelepipeds on two parallel lines.

GraphClass.name: strictly clique irreducible
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_1045 if every edge in the graph lies in a unique clique.

Let G be a graph and U be the set of universal vertices of G. G is gc_1047 iff
G is gc_889 or
G\U is both gc_486 and gc_889, and |U|>= 2.

GraphClass.name: trapezoepiped
GraphClass.note:
Let L and M be two parallel lines in 3-dimensional Euclidean space. Without loss of generality assume L={(.,0,0)} and M={(.,1,0)}.
A special trapezeopiped on L and M is either
the convex hull of eight points
A = (a,1,0)A' = (a,1,a')
B = (b,0,0)B' = (b,0,b')
C = (c,0,0)C' = (c,0,a')
D = (d,1,0)D' = (d,1,b')
for some a,b,c,d,a',b' >= 0 with ADBC a trapezoid between L and M; or
the line segment between (a,1,z) and (b,0,z) for some a,b,z >= 0.
A graph is a gc_1048 graph if it is the intersection graph of special trapezoepipeds on two parallel lines.

GraphClass.name: bounded bitolerance
GraphClass.note: Another name for gc_341 graphs.

GraphClass.name: bounded cutwidth
GraphClass.note:
The cutwidth of a graph G is the smallest integer k such that the vertices of G can be arranged in a linear layout v1,...,vn in such a way that, for every i = 1,...,n - 1, there are at most k edges with one endpoint in {v1.....vi}. and the other in {vi+1,...,vn}.
A graph is in gc_1052 if its cutwidth is at most a given constant k.

GraphClass.name: bounded degree
GraphClass.note: A graph is of gc_1053 when no vertex has more than k neighbours, for some given constant k.

GraphClass.name: grid graph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1057 iff it is an induced subgraph of a gc_464.

GraphClass.name: solid grid graph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1058 iff it is a gc_1057 that can be embedded in the plane such that the vertices lie on integer coordinates, the edges have unit length and all interior faces have unit area. (The first two conditions hold for every gc_1057, the third says that the embedding contains no `holes'.)

GraphClass.name: self-complementary
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_1059 if it is isomorphic to its complement.

GraphClass.name: VPG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1060 if it is the vertex intersection graph of paths in a gc_464.

GraphClass.name: B_k-VPG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1061 if it is the vertex intersection graph of paths with at most k bends in a gc_464.

GraphClass.name: B_3-VPG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1062 if it is the vertex intersection graph of paths with at most 3 bends in a gc_464.

GraphClass.name: B_2-VPG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1063 if it is the vertex intersection graph of paths with at most 2 bends in a gc_464.

GraphClass.name: B_1-VPG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1064 graph if it is the vertex intersection graph of paths with at most 1 bends in a gc_464.

GraphClass.name: B_0-VPG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1065 if it is the vertex intersection graph of paths with at most 0 bends in a gc_464.

algo.name: Clique
algo.note: Given that path presentation ref_1545.

GraphClass.name: 4-colorable
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_1071 iff it can be partitioned in 4 independent sets.

GraphClass.name: NLCT-width 1
GraphClass.note:
The NLCT-width of a graph is the number of different labels that is needed to construct the graph using the following operations:
creation of a vertex with label i,
renaming labels according to a function over the labels (so multiple labels can be renamed by a single operation),
uniting two labeled graphs G and J according to a relation S over the labels: The disjoint union of G and J is created and edges between v in G and w in J are added precisely when the pair (label(v), label(w)) is in S. Furthermore, if S is non-empty, then J must consist of a single vertex.
A graph is in gc_1072 iff its NLCT-width is at most 1.

GraphClass.name: linear NLC-width 1
GraphClass.note:
The linear NLC-width of a graph is the number of different labels that is needed to construct the graph using the following operations:
creation of a vertex with label i,
renaming labels according to a function over the labels (so multiple labels can be renamed by a single operation),
uniting two labeled graphs G and J according to a relation S over the labels: The disjoint union of G and J is created and edges between v in G and w in J are added precisely when the pair (label(v), label(w)) is in S. Furthermore, either G or J must consist of a single vertex.
A graph is in gc_1073 iff its linear NLC-width is at most 1.
A graph is gc_1075 iff it can be created from a gc_328 graph G, by replacing every vertex in the independent set of the gc_39 partition of G by a clique.

GraphClass.name: linear cliquewidth 2
GraphClass.note:
The linear cliquewidth of a graph is the number of different labels that is needed to construct the graph using the following operations:
creation of a vertex with label i,
disjoint union of a graph and a single labeled vertex,
renaming labels i to label j,
connecting all vertices with label i to all vertices with label j.
A graph is in gc_1077 iff its linear cliquewidth is at most 2.

GraphClass.name: 2-track
GraphClass.note: Given 2 parallel lines, a graph is a gc_1079 graph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consists of 2 intervals, one on each line.

GraphClass.name: 3-track
GraphClass.note: Given 3 parallel lines, a graph is a gc_1079 graph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consists of 3 intervals, one on each line.

GraphClass.name: unit 3-track
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1081 iff it is a gc_1080 graph with an intersection model consisting of unit length intervals.

GraphClass.name: unit 2-track
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1082 iff it is a gc_1079 graph with an intersection model consisting of unit length intervals.

GraphClass.name: unit 3-interval
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1083 graph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consist of 3 intervals of length 1 on a real line.

GraphClass.name: 2-circular arc
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1084 graph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consist of 2 arcs of a circle.

GraphClass.name: unit 2-circular arc
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1085 graph iff it is a gc_1084 graph with an intersection model whose objects consist of 2 unit length arcs of a circle.

GraphClass.name: 2-circular track
GraphClass.note: Given 2 disjoint circles, a graph is a gc_1086 graph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consists of 2 arcs, one on each circle.

GraphClass.name: unit 2-circular track
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1087 graph iff it is a gc_1086 graph with an intersection model whose objects are 2 unit length arcs.

GraphClass.name: 3-circular track
GraphClass.note: Given 3 disjoint circles, a graph is a gc_1086 graph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consists of 3 arcs, one on each circle.

GraphClass.name: unit 3-circular track
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1089 graph iff it is a gc_1088 graph with an intersection model whose objects are 3 unit length arcs.

GraphClass.name: maximum degree 7
GraphClass.note: A graph is of gc_1090 when no vertex has more than 7 neighbours.

GraphClass.name: hamiltonian
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_1092 if it has a simple cycle that goes through all vertices of the graph.

GraphClass.name: fully cycle extendable
GraphClass.note:
A cycle in a graph G is extendable if there exists a cycle C' in G that consists of the vertices in C plus a single new vertex.
If every non-hamiltonian cycle in G is extendable, then G is cycle extendable.
If G is cycle extendable and every vertex of G belongs to a triangle of G, then G is gc_1093.
Every gc_1098 graph is gc_1093 ref_1559.

GraphClass.name: k-regular, fixed k\ge 3
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_1099 if every vertex in G has degree k.

GraphClass.name: cubic
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_1100 if every vertex in G has degree 3.
This class is not to be confused with gc_1177 graphs.

GraphClass.name: 4-regular
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_1101 if every vertex in G has degree 4.

GraphClass.name: 5-regular
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_1104 if every vertex in G has degree 5.

GraphClass.name: k-regular, fixed k\ge 6
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_1105 if every vertex in G has degree k.

GraphClass.name: equimatchable
GraphClass.note:
A set M of edges of a graph is a matching if each vertex in G belongs to at most one edge in M. A matching M is maximal if no other matching strictly contains M.
A graph G is gc_1112 if all maximal matchings in G have the same cardinality.
A graph G is gc_1112 if every maximal matching is a maximum matching.
A graph G is gc_1112 if its gc_249 graph is gc_415.

GraphClass.name: well-dominated
GraphClass.note: A graph G is well-dominated if every minimal dominating set is a minimum dominating set.

GraphClass.name: triangular grid graph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1118 iff it is an induced subgraph of a tiling of the plane with equilateral triangles.

GraphClass.name: maximum degree 6
GraphClass.note: A graph is of gc_1119 when no vertex has more than 6 neighbours.

GraphClass.name: solid triangular grid graph
GraphClass.note:
Let G be gc_1118 and let T be a planar tiling with triangles that contains G.
A hole of G is an interior face of G that contains a vertex in V(T)\V(G).
A graph is a gc_1124 iff it is a gc_1118 that has no holes.

GraphClass.name: maximum degree 5
GraphClass.note: A graph is of gc_1139 when no vertex has more than 5 neighbours.

GraphClass.name: linearly convex triangular grid graph
GraphClass.note: A gc_1118 G is a gc_1141 iff every line which contains an edge of the underling triangular tiling is either a line segment (a path in G), or a point (a vertex in G) or empty.

GraphClass.name: almost claw-free
GraphClass.note: Let A be the set of vertices in a graph G that are the centers of an induced claw. A graph G is gc_1145 if A is independent and for every x in A: the subgraph induced by N(x) has a dominating set of size at most 2.

GraphClass.name: Delaunay
GraphClass.note:
Let P be a set of points in the plane. A triangulation of P is a subdivsion of the plane by edges between vertices in P, such that no edge connecting two vertices in P can be added without destroying planarity.
A Delaunay triangulation is a triangulation D(P) such that no point in P is inside the circumference of any triangle in D(P).
A graph is a gc_1147 graph if it is the Delaunay triangulation of some set of points in the plane.

GraphClass.name: distance regular
GraphClass.note:
Let $N^k(v)$ be the set of vertices $x$ in $G$ with $d(v,x) = k$.
A graph $G$ is gc_1148 if there are numbers $a_i, b_i, c_i$ for $0\le i\le d(G)$ such that if $d(x,y) = j$ then \[\begin{array}{ll} |N(y) \cap N_{j-1}(x)| &= c_j\\ |N(y) \cap N_{j}(x)| &= a_j\\ |N(y) \cap N_{j+1}(x)| &= b_j \end{array}\]

GraphClass.name: k-regular, fixed k
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_1149 if every vertex in G has degree k.

GraphClass.name: tree convex
GraphClass.note: A gc_69 graph $B=(X,Y,E)$ is gc_1150 if a tree $T=(X,F)$ can be defined, such that for every vertex $y\in Y$, the neighbourhood of $y$ induces a subtree in $T$.

GraphClass.name: star convex
GraphClass.note: A gc_69 graph $B=(X,Y,E)$ is gc_1151 if a tree $T=(X,F)$ can be defined, such that $T$ is a star and for every vertex $y\in Y$, the neighbourhood of $y$ induces a subtree in $T$.

GraphClass.name: triad convex
GraphClass.note: A gc_69 graph $B=(X,Y,E)$ is gc_1152 if a tree $T=(X,F)$ can be defined, such that $T$ is a triad and for every vertex $y\in Y$, the neighbourhood of $y$ induces a subtree in $T$.

GraphClass.name: circle-trapezoid
GraphClass.note:
A circle trapezoid is the region that lies between two non-crossing chords of a circle. So if $ab$ and $cd$ are non-crossing chords, with their endpoints in the order $abcd$ on the circle, the boundary of the circle trapezoid $abcd$ consists of the chord $ab$, the arc $bc$, the chord $cd$ and the arc $da$. Alternatively, a circle trapezoid is the convex hull of two disjoint arcs on the circle.
A graph is a gc_1154 graph if it is the intersection graph of circle trapezoids on a common circle.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Assuming the intersection model is given ref_1120.

algo.name: Weighted clique
algo.note: Assuming the intersection model is given ref_1120.

GraphClass.name: circular trapezoid
GraphClass.note:
Given two concentric circle $C$ and $D$, a circular trapezoid is the region that lies between two non-crossing line segments that connect points on $C$ with points on $D$. So if $ab$ and $cd$ are non-crossing chords, with $a,c$ on $C$ and $b,d$ on $D$, the boundary of the circular trapezoid $abcd$ consists of the line segment $ab$, the arc $bd$, the segment $dc$ and the arc $ca$.
A graph is a gc_1155 graph if it is the intersection graph of circular trapezoids.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Assuming the intersection model is given ref_1196.

GraphClass.name: circular strip
GraphClass.note: Another name for gc_1154 graphs.

GraphClass.name: circle-$n$-gon, fixed $n$
GraphClass.note:
A circle $n$-gon is the region that lies between two $n$ or fewer non-crossing chords of a circle, no chord connecting the arcs between two other chords; the side of a circle $n$-gon are either chords or arcs of the circle.
A graph is a gc_1157 graph if it is the intersection graph of circle $n$-gons in a common circle.

algo.name: Weighted feedback vertex set
algo.note: Assuming the model is given ref_1595.

GraphClass.name: alternation
GraphClass.note:
Given a word $W$ over the alphabet $V$, we say that the letters $x,y\in V$ alternate in $W$ if between every two occurrences of $x$ there is a $y$ ($x,y,x$ need not be consecutive) and between every two occurrences of $y$ there is an $x$.
A graph $G=(V,E)$ is an gc_1158 graph if there exists a word $W$ over the alphabet $V$ such that $x, y$ ($x\not= y$) alternate in $W$ iff $xy$ is an edge.

An orientation of a graph $G=(V,E)$ is semi-transitive if it is acyclic and for any directed path $v_1,..,v_k$ either $v_1v_k\not\in E$ or $v_iv_j\in E$ for all $1\le i\lt j\lt k$.
A graph is an gc_1158 graph iff it is semi-transitively orientable.
Is every graph of gc_717 an gc_1158 graph? ref_1598
What is the maximum alternation number of a graph? ref_1598

GraphClass.name: binary Hamming
GraphClass.note:
The Hamming distance between two vectors is the number of positions in which the two vectors differ.
A graph is an gc_1159 graph if its vertices can be labelled by fixed length bitvectors such that the distance between any two vertices equals the Hamming distance between the corresponding labels.

Define the relation $\Theta$ on the edges of an undirected graph as $pq \Theta rs$ iff $d(p,r) + d(q,s) \not= d(p,s) + d(q,r)$.
A graph G is a gc_1159 graph if G is gc_69 and $\Theta$ is an equivalence relation on the edges of $G$.

GraphClass.name: partial cube
GraphClass.note: Alias for gc_1161

GraphClass.name: isometric subgraph of a hypercube
GraphClass.note: A subgraph G of H is an isometric subgraph if for every two vertices, the distance between them in G equals the distance in H.

GraphClass.name: Hamming
GraphClass.note:
The Hamming distance between two vectors is the number of positions in which the two vectors differ.
A graph is a gc_1162 graph if its vertices can be labelled by fixed length vectors over a finite alphabet such that the distance between any two vertices equals the Hamming distance between the corresponding labels.
A graph is a gc_1162 graph if it is an isometric subgraph of a gc_1163 graph.

GraphClass.name: complete Hamming
GraphClass.note:
The Hamming distance between two vectors is the number of positions in which the two vectors differ.
Let $r_1,..r_d$ be given integers and let $V$ be the set of vectors $a_1,..,a_d$ with $0\le a_i\lt r_i$. Let $E$ be the set of pairs of tuples that have Hamming distance 1. Then $G=(V,E)$ is a gc_1163 graph.
A graph is a gc_1162 graph if it is the Cartesian product of $d$ (not necessarily isomorphic) complete graphs.

GraphClass.name: hypercube
GraphClass.note: A gc_1164 is the gc_1163 graph for the alphabet $\{0,1\}$.
A gc_1164 is the Cartesian product of $d$ K_2s.

algo.name: Hamiltonian cycle
algo.note: Every gc_1164 with more than 2 vertices is gc_1092 ref_1613.

algo.name: Hamiltonian path
algo.note: Every gc_1164 with more than 2 vertices is gc_1092 ref_1613.

GraphClass.name: weakly median
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_1167 if it is gc_222 and does not contain two vertices with an unconnected triple of common neighbours.

GraphClass.name: almost median
GraphClass.note:
Define the relation $\Theta$ on the edges of an undirected graph as $pq \Theta rs$ iff $d(p,r) + d(q,s) \not= d(p,s) + d(q,r)$.
For an edge $pq$ of a graph $G=(V,E)$ let $W_{pq}=\{w \mid w\in V \text{ and } d(w,p) \lt d(w,q)\}$ and let $U_{pq} = \{u\in W_{pq} \mid u \text{ is adjacent to a vertex in } W_{qp}\}$.
A graph $G$ is gc_1170 if it is gc_69 and $\Theta$ is an equivalence relation on the edges of $G$ and for any edge $pq$ of $G$, the subgraph induced by $U_{pq}$ is isometric.

GraphClass.name: semi-median
GraphClass.note:
Define the relation $\Theta$ on the edges of an undirected graph as $pq \Theta rs$ iff $d(p,r) + d(q,s) \not= d(p,s) + d(q,r)$.
For an edge $pq$ of a graph $G=(V,E)$ let $W_{pq}=\{w \mid w\in V \text{ and } d(w,p) \lt d(w,q)\}$ and let $U_{pq} = \{u\in W_{pq} \mid u \text{ is adjacent to a vertex in } W_{qp}\}$.
A graph $G$ is gc_1171 if it is gc_69 and $\Theta$ is an equivalence relation on the edges of $G$ and for any edge $pq$ of $G$, the subgraph induced by $U_{pq}$ is connected.

GraphClass.name: premedian
GraphClass.note: Alias for gc_1171

GraphClass.name: unit grid intersection
GraphClass.note: A gc_739 graph is a gc_1173 graph if it has an intersection model in which all line segments have unit length.

GraphClass.name: cubical
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_1177 iff it is an induced subgraph of a gc_1164.
This class is not to be confused with gc_1100 graphs.

GraphClass.name: rigid circuit
GraphClass.note: Synonym for gc_32.

GraphClass.name: rectangle intersection
GraphClass.note: gc_1179 graphs or plain rectangle graphs are synonyms for gc_239.

GraphClass.name: apex
GraphClass.note: A graph $G$ is an gc_1181 graph, if it contains a vertex $v$ such that $G-v$ is gc_43.

GraphClass.name: 5-colorable
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_1182 iff it can be partitioned in 5 independent sets.

GraphClass.name: k--outerplanar
GraphClass.note: A graph G is gc_1184 if for k=1, G is gc_110 and for k>1, G has a planar embedding such that if all vertices on the exterior face are deleted, the connected components of the remaining graph are all (k-1) outerplanar.

GraphClass.name: strongly regular
GraphClass.note: A gc_1185 graph with parameters $(n,k,\lambda,\mu)$ is a graph on $n$ vertices which is regular of degree $k$, any two adjacent vertices have exactly $\lambda$ common neighbours and any two nonadjacent vertices have exactly $\mu$ common neighbours.
The parameters $(n,k,\lambda,\mu)$ satisfy the equation \[ k(k-\lambda-1) = (n-k-1)\mu \]

GraphClass.name: distance regular of diameter 2
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_1186 iff it is gc_1148 and its diameter is 2.
A graph is gc_1186 iff it is connected and gc_1185.

GraphClass.name: walk regular
GraphClass.note:
A walk is an alternating sequence of vertices and edges, beginning and ending with a vertex, where each vertex is incident to both the edge that precedes it and the edge that follows it in the sequence, and where the vertices that precede and follow an edge are the end vertices of that edge. A walk is closed if its first and last vertices are the same.
A graph is gc_1187 if, for every non-negative integer $i$ and vertex $v$ the number of closed walks of length $i$ starting at $v$ depends only on $i$, not on $v$.
A graph is gc_1187 if the characteristic polynomials of all its vertex-deleted subgraphs are the same.

GraphClass.name: edge regular
GraphClass.note: A gc_1188 graph with parameters $(n,k,\lambda)$ is a graph on $n$ vertices which is regular of degree $k$, any two adjacent vertices have exactly $\lambda$ common neighbours.

GraphClass.name: Deza
GraphClass.note: A gc_1189 graph with parameters $(\lambda,\mu)$ is a graph such that any two adjacent vertices have exactly $\lambda$ common neighbours and any two nonadjacent vertices have exactly $\mu$ common neighbours.
A graph is gc_1190 iff any two vertices have at most two common neighbours.

GraphClass.name: (0,2)-graph
GraphClass.note: A gc_1191 is a connected graph such that any two vertices have either 0 or 2 common neighbours.
The gc_488 graphs are different, but have a similar naming scheme.

GraphClass.name: rectagraph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1192 iff it is gc_371 and a gc_1191.

A semibiplane is a connected point-block incidence structure such that any two points are in either 0 or 2 common blocks and any two blocks have either 0 or 2 common points.
A graph is in gc_1193 iff it is the incidence graph of a semibiplane.
A connected graph is in gc_1194 iff it is one of K_1, K_2, K_3, K_4, C_4, C_5, \co{3K_2}.

GraphClass.name: 2-strongly regular
GraphClass.note: A gc_1195 graph with parameters $(n,k_1\lt k_2,\lambda,\mu)$ is a graph on $n$ vertices in which every vertex is of degree $k_1$ or $k_2$, any two adjacent vertices have exactly $\lambda$ common neighbours and any two nonadjacent vertices have exactly $\mu$ common neighbours.
gc_1195 graphs have diameter at most 2.

GraphClass.name: adjoint
GraphClass.note:
Let $H=(X,V)$ be a directed graph, possibly with multi-edges. The adjoint $G=(V,U)$ of $H$ has vertex set $V$ and $x\rightarrow y$ is an arc in $G$ iff the terminal endpoint of $x$ in $H$ is the initial endpoint of $y$ in $H$.
A directed graph $G$ is an gc_1197 if there is some directed graph $H$ such that $G$ is the adjoint of $H$.

Let $N^+(x)$ be the out-neighbourhood of $x$.
A directed graph $G$ is an gc_1197 iff for any two vertices $x,y$ of $G$: If $N^+(x) \cap N^+(y) \neq\emptyset$ then $N^+(x) = N^+(y)$.

GraphClass.name: quasi-adjoint
GraphClass.note:
Let $N^+(x)$ be the out-neighbourhood of $x$.
A directed graph $G$ is a gc_1198 iff for any two vertices $x,y$ of $G$: If $N^+(x) \cap N^+(y) \neq\emptyset$ then $N^+(x) \subseteq N^+(y)$ or $N^+(y) \subseteq N^+(x)$, that is, the out-neighborhoods are nested.

GraphClass.name: directed line
GraphClass.note: A directed graph $G$ is a gc_1199 graph if it is the gc_1197 of a directed graph without multi-edges.

GraphClass.name: partial directed line
GraphClass.note: A directed graph is a gc_1200 graph iff it is an arbitrary subgraph (not necessarily induced) of a gc_1199.

GraphClass.name: unicyclic
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_1202 if it is connected and contains precisely one cycle.

GraphClass.name: k-SEG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1203 graph if it is the intersection graph of piecewise linear curves in the plane, such that each curve consists of at most k line segments.

GraphClass.name: 2-SEG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1204 graph if it is the intersection graph of piecewise linear curves in the plane, such that each curve consists of at most 2 line segments.

GraphClass.name: B_1-VPG contact
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1205 graph if it is gc_1064 with the additional condition that no two paths in the model have an interior point in common.

GraphClass.name: Laman
GraphClass.note: A graph with $n$ vertices is a gc_1206 graph iff, for all $k$, every $k$-vertex induced subgraph has at most $2k-3$ edges and the graph itself has exactly $2n-3$ edges.

A graph is a gc_1206 graph iff it can be constructed from an edge by a sequence of the following two (so called Henneberg) operations:
Add a new vertex and connect it with two new edges to two existing vertices.
Choose an existing edge $(v,w)$ and a third vertex $x$. Remove the edge $(v,w)$. Add a new vertex $u$ and edges $(u,v), (u,w), (u,x)$
Laman graphs derive their name from Gerard Laman and are of importance in rigidity theory, where they characterize minimally rigid planar bar-and-joint systems.

GraphClass.name: strict B_1-VPG contact
GraphClass.note: A graph is a gc_1208 graph (called L-contact graph in ref_1638) if it is a gc_1205 graph with the additional condition that every path in the model has 1 bend.
There are gc_1208 graphs that are not gc_1206 graphs (e.g. K_4). All gc_1208 graphs are gc_43 and satisfy $|E(W)| \le 2|W|-2$ for all $W \subseteq V$. Are these conditions sufficient? ref_1638.

GraphClass.name: generically minimally rigid
GraphClass.note: gc_1209 is another name for gc_1206 graphs.

GraphClass.name: Mycielski
GraphClass.note:
Given a graph $G$, $M(G)$ is constructed as follows: Start with $G$ and for every vertex $v_i$ in $G$ add a vertex $u_i$. Make $u_i$ adjacent to all vertices in $N_G(v_i)$. Finally add a vertex $w$ which is adjacent to all $u_i$.
The gc_1215 graphs are defined as follows:
K_2 is a gc_1215 graph.
If $G$ is a gc_1215 graph, then $M(G)$ is a gc_1215 graph.

GraphClass.name: hereditary sat
GraphClass.note: A graph $G$ is a gc_1218 if its vertex set can be partitioned into two sets $A$ and $B$ (both possibly empty), such that $G[A]$ is a clique, every vertex in $G[B]$ has degree at most 1 and in $G$ there is no triangle with one vertex in $A$ and two in $B$.

GraphClass.name: locally split
GraphClass.note: A graph is gc_1219 if the open neighbourhood of each vertex induces a gc_39 graph.

GraphClass.name: (1,2)-split
GraphClass.note: A graph $G$ is gc_1220 iff its vertex set can be partitioned into two sets $A, B$, such that $G[A]$ is a clique and $G[B]$ is gc_371.
Give a forbidden subgraph characterisation of gc_1220 graphs. ref_1670

GraphClass.name: (p,q)-split
GraphClass.note: A graph $G$ is ($p$,$q$)-split iff its vertex set can be partitioned into two sets $A, B$, such that the largest independent set in $A$ has at most $p$ vertices and the largest clique in $B$ has at most $q$ vertices.
